PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Retail Trading Hours

SPEECH.SPEAKER: CHIPP

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 7,269 citizens of Australia :

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we wish to express our strongest opposition to any deregulation of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
2. That if trading hours are deregulated in the Australian Capital Territory the present restrictions on trading hours in other parts of Australia may be lifted.

3. Past performances have proven that longer trading hours do not lead to increased sales. However, they do increase costs, because shops have to be staffed for longer periods. To cover these increased costs, retailers are forced to increase prices and reduce staff levels. This means that longer trading hours increase both prices and unemployment.
4. There is no real consumer demand for longer trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory.
5. The deregulation of trading hours would force small Retail Companies out of business.
6. Extended trading hours would gravely disrupt weekend recreation and family life of shop assistants.

Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should: Ensure that retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory continue to be regulated by Ordinance as happened in the past.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: GILES

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 250 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that some single supporting parents are unfairly disadvantaged in having chosen to care for children full-time during the formative years, believing such care was essential to their well-being; and that women without dependent children, and who are under 50 years of age are not eligible for a continuing pension. These women have devoted their whole lives to their families and do not have skills relevant to the present employment situation. Their future prospects, with increasing age and length of time out of the workforce are a deterrent to employers. Skilled workers find it difficult to obtain employment and unskilled workers find it even more difficult. Unemployment benefit was not designed for long term usage and the low rate of payment plus the work tests over a long period of time lead to a general decline in the physical and mental health, with the result that the women are being placed on sickness benefits. Sickness benefits however, were also designed for short term usage and is unable to provide security for these women.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should
(i) Amend the Social Services Act to reduce the age of eligibility for a Class B Widows Pension from 50 to 40 years; and
(ii) Expand existing training schemes to include women taken off supporting Parents' Benefit.
(iii) Provide rehabilitation for women with disabilities which preclude them from the paid work force.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament House assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The introduction of the Child Care Act (1972) demonstrated the Government's acceptance of the need for, in the words of Mr Lynch when introducing the Bill, '. . . the development of child day care facilities of good quality throughout the Commonwealth'. To achieve this objective it must be realised that:
(a) To provide, or encourage the provision of anything less than the highest quality care is a failure to recognise the potential value of day care to many children in our society.
(b) The provision of child care is highly labour intensive.
(c) Top quality child day care requires that supervisory staff be professionally oriented and qualified.
(d) The work of providing child care is physically and mentally demanding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government enact a policy which will ensure that all existing and proposed subsidised child day-care centres receive a level of funding to meet the cost of:
(a) 90 per cent of ALL staff salaries including ancillary staff such as clerical and cooks.
(b) the maintenance of staff: child ratios at-
(i) One (1) care giver per four (4) full time equivalent children under the age of three (3) years and
(ii) One (1) care giver per six and one half (6.5) full time equivalent children of the ages of three (3) years and over.
(c) recurrent expenditure on new and replacement equipment at a rate of then cents (10c) per child hour of care provided.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: PLUMBERS, DRAINERS AND GASFITTERS BOARD ORDINANCE 1982

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 12 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Plumbers, Drainers and Gasfitters Board Ordinance 1982, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 74 of 1982 and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable senators are aware the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances deals with technical matters on the Senate's behalf. The Committee realises its responsibility to inform the Senate of reasons for its actions, both when notices of disallowance are being given and when the Committee decides to withdraw its notices. However, the detail which has to be given when making these statements not only tests the patience of all honourable senators, including me, but frequently means that the explanation is not understood. In future, therefore, as a general practice I propose to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a detailed statement of explanation, which honourable senators may subsequently read if they are concerned about it, and also to give a brief explanation to the chamber which I hope will enable honourable senators to understand what I have been talking about. This ordinance has a somewhat Monty Pythonesque name of the Plumbers, Drainers and Gasfitters Board Ordinance 1982. The Committee has some concern about notification of appeal rights to persons affected by a decision by the Board to cancel or suspend a licence. The purpose of this notice is simply to preserve the Committee's rights while awaiting advice from the Minister. I seek leave to have a more detailed statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Sub-section 33 (2) of this Ordinance provides that the validity of a decision by the Plumbers, Drainers and Gasfitters Board to cancel or suspend a certificate or licence is not to be affected by failure to notify a person that cancellation or suspension is subject to a right of appeal. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee has asked the Minister for the Capital Territory whether notification of a right of appeal will routinely be made to all persons affected , and awaits the Minister's advice on the matter. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In the current public debate on the Government's proposed wages freeze some critics are recalling the experience of a similar move in 1977. I ask: Do the circumstances today make a call for a freeze of wages and salaries more urgent, more compelling and therefore more capable of success than was the case five years ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I pointed out that there is widespread interest, and indeed active measures are being taken, by ordinary individuals in the community to ensure that they do not, by their own seeking of higher wages, disemploy others. Perhaps the best answer that can be given as to the justification for what is being done today is in the editorial of the Australian Financial Review of today. It is important to understand what that editorial states:

ANSWER.PARA: There is no way city populations-and that means everybody, not just the blue collar union members-can continue to increase their real incomes in the face of the situation facing Australia in 1983. One way or another, belt-tightening is inevitable. If it isn't imposed by a Government wages freeze it will be imposed by a collapse in employment as the jobless percentage heads into double figures and wages claims disappear as employees cling with increasing desperation to their existing jobs.
The editorial goes on to state:

The need now is to divert sufficient income from the well off employed majority to those who are unemployed, or about to be so, while maintaining overall demand at levels sufficient to avoid further downward multiplier effects on employment prospects.

It is not an alternative simply to suggest larger deficit finance, or huge additional expenditures, as France's Francois Mitterrand found out the hard way when four-fifths of his expansionary stimulus leaked away into imports, leaving France with the resulting inflation but not much in the way of employment stimulus.

The situation now is far more urgent than in 1977. In 1977 the world recession had not bitten so hard on Australia. In the last six months the overseas recession has very markedly reduced exports from Australia and has cut down, therefore, on our capacity for employment. If we are to continue to employ people we must stop the upward surge of wages and in fact by so doing carry out what the Australian Financial Review says is inevitable, unless we are to disemploy more people.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether he agrees with the statement issued by Mr Anthony, the Acting Prime Minister, on Monday of this week in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Over the most recent six months for which data is available, the annual rate of wage increase has been about eight per cent for the OECD.

Is it not a fact that the average increase in inflation for Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries during the same period was 7.9 per cent? Do these figures not indicate that in the OECD real wages have kept pace with inflation? I also ask the Minister whether in the light of those circumstances he will--

TALK.START.PARA: —Exceeded inflation.
—Yes, exceeded it.
—In Australia.
—And in the OECD.
—Order!

—I am sorry, Mr President. I am getting some help from one of the Minister's colleagues. I ask the Minister whether, in the light of those figures , he will identify those countries, other than the United Kingdom, which he referred to yesterday as having lowered real wages.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said yesterday was that the countries of the OECD were making attempts to lower real wages--
—You didn't say that.

—Hansard will show those things. Let me say that the policies of the OECD countries, of Western Europe, are to get major wage restraint in order to bring down inflation. I am not sure whether the figures quoted by Senator Button are accurate. I can check up on those. I will certainly get further information on those countries. Australia, on the other hand, has had its real wages running very considerably ahead of inflation for quite some time. The main thing, as indeed the Australian Financial Review makes clear, is for us to bear down on inflation. I repeat that Mr Hayden made it clear when he was Treasurer that if one wants to stop unemployment one must bear down on inflation; that upward surges of costs create more unemployment. I repeat also that the essential situation is that the majority of costs ultimately are wages. If we want to reduce costs we must have wage restraint. I commend not just one but the three or four answers that I gave yesterday on this question as to the picture. What I have said in effect is that the countries of Western Europe- facing very high inflation indeed, in some cases inflation twice as high as that in Australia-have embarked upon a policy of wage restraint in order to combat unemployment. That is a principle identical with the one outlined by the then Labor Treasurer, the now Labor Leader, Mr Hayden, and I commend it.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister, in his answer, said that we can take our pick from the answers he gave yesterday. But my question was directed to a particular point. I ask whether this happened yesterday. I quote from yesterday's Hansard:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: — . . . In countries such as the United States of America, the United Kingdom and some other European countries there has been a reduction in wages.
—In real wages?
—In real wages.

ANSWER.PARA: Did he not say that yesterday?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course. I did not invite the Senate to take its pick from the answers I gave yesterday. I invited the Senate to look at a series of questions and supplementary questions, the totality of the answer being what I have just said, which is that the countries of the OECD, facing inordinate unemployment and then inflation, have in fact called upon their people for major wage restraint because by wage restraint they would get down inflation. Having got inflation down they would then be taking the first steps towards re- employment. As yet they have not been able to get to a point where the recession has bottomed and re-employment can occur. In every country of the free world there is a recognition that the first thing to do to overcome unemployment and prepare for the future is to get costs down. The essence of costs, of course, is wages.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Since to most Australians it is a matter of simple common sense that we should not go on spending money that we do not have on imports at an ever increasing rate, will the Minister undertake to put to Cabinet a simple proposition to introduce and pass next week a Bill to amend the Industries Assistance Commission Act 1973 so that the Government can re-assume the power it lost under the Whitlam Government to impose import quotas at any time our international insolvency demands that this action be taken? To ensure that such a move has the greatest national impact will the Minister responsible seek Australian Labor Party support for the amendment before it is introduced so that it can have the unanimous support of all parties in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some months ago the Government made a decision not to reduce protection even though it had a series of recommendations from the Industries Assistance Commission before it. The Government has decided to maintain the present levels of protection. The Government faces the situation where one of the troubles in the world in the restriction of trade has been increased protection; countries are putting up walls around themselves and, therefore, not giving opportunities to countries such as Australia to trade. The desirable thing would be, as in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussions, to have a world in which people put down their barriers. But it is a real world at this moment and the Government does not intend to accept the IAC 's recommendations regarding lowering protection. I will refer the matter that has been raised by Senator Siddons to the responsible Minister and ask him to put it under study.

—I ask the Minister for Finance whether it is possible to indicate what proportion of an average consumer price index rise is due to the effect of wage increases. How long after a wage freeze has been implemented would a favourable effect on the CPI be apparent? Is it the intention of the Government to attempt to limit the freeze to Public Service wages or will there be an attempt to implement a more effective general wages freeze?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I cannot be precise about the proportion of increases in prices that could be attributed to wages. I think it is obvious that included in prices are the costs of materials and labour and the profit that is expected to be returned on the investment. In measuring the effect of wages, we are aware-I think I quoted this figure earlier this week-that, in the 12 months to September, the adult male wage increased by about 18 per cent. If one combines that with the reduction of hours that took place at the same time and looks at the decrease in hours that have been worked, one would be looking at a figure close to 20 per cent over that 12 month period. During the same period, the consumer price index rose by about 12 per cent. So one surely has a self-evident fact that there is a big component of wage effect in that increase in the CPI. Senator Jessop, in the second part of his question, asked about the timing of the effect of a wages freeze. I think that also would be difficult to be precise about because what we are looking at, in current economic circumstances, is a return to profitability for some enterprises that are unable to continue because of lack of profitability. It would, therefore, be some time before the effect of the wages freeze on increases would be evident.

ANSWER.PARA: The third part of the honourable senator's question related to whether we were talking only about the public sector wage increases. It was made clear in the statement initially made by the Acting Prime Minister that we would hope to see public and private sector wages show this restraint on increases, probably for a 12 month period; that matter would be discussed at the forthcoming Premiers Conference. If we are to look at the advantages that would come from a wages freeze on increases it would need to have effect in the private sector as well as in the public sector. The effect of the restraint in the public sector would be, in our terms of the proposal, simply to release funds that could be made available for spending and for providing employment opportunities, whereas the restraint in the private sector would enable many businesses to return to profitability or to continue to trade and manufacture. So, the short answer to the last part of the question is that it is envisaged that the private and the public sectors would be involved in any proposed restraint on wage increases.

—Has the Leader of the Government in the Senate had his attention drawn to a Press release by Senator Mason which asks that the Government study a major program which successfully combatted unemployment in America during the Great Depression? In that Press release, Senator Mason said that he was disappointed that Senator Sir John Carrick's initial response to the idea showed that he had very little interest in it or understanding of it and no apparent desire to do anything about it. In view of Senator Mason's response, will the Minister expand his earlier reply and tell us whether, on this important matter, he has 'no apparent desire to do anything?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting situation that when Senator Mason asks the question members of the Opposition welcome the answer, but when a Government senator asks the question apparently they do not. The fact is that I very well recall the Rooseveltian era. I was both a high school student and a young economics student at the time, so I am very well aware of the New Deal, the National Recovery Act, the Agricultural Adjustment Act and the slogan 'We do our part'. I understand that. What I said the other day and what I repeat is this: One cannot compare the major Depression of the 1930s with today's recession. The fact is that in those days there was a negative interest rate and negative inflation. There was gross unemployment. I repeat that there was no inflation and no rising interest rates. In fact, interest rates were touching the floor. It was virtually impossible to lend money. Today we have an entirely different situation. It is quite different from the Keynesian era. After all, members of the Opposition are again knocking their own leader. Honourable senators will remember that their leader in his Budget Speech as Treasurer said that we were no longer in the Keynesian era. The Keynesian era was an era in which there was gross unemployment, low interest rates and low inflation. Fundamentally one cannot compare the two eras. In Australia we are trying to prepare ourselves so that when the recession dissipates Australia will be ready in terms of skills and job experience to seize that opportunity. We are asking for a forgoing of wage increases to stop further unemployment and to create job opportunities. We are saying that at the government level we should be able to make available some $700m worth of new job creation without putting pressure on the deficit, and in the private sector some billions of dollars should be made available for job creation if wage restraint is exercised in that sector.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a very sensible approach in an era which is entirely different from Rooseveltian times. The Rooseveltian times demanded that there should be huge increases in the American deficit to finance various projects. I emphatically make it clear that, as the Australian Financial Review said this morning, if we increase the deficit we will increase inflation and unemployment. It is no use members of the Australian Labor Party laughing. They are sneering once again at their leader. Mr Hayden, as Treasurer, made it abundantly clear-he is on record in Hansard-that increasing the deficit would increase inflation and unemployment . He said that bearing down on inflation and costs would rectify unacceptably high unemployment. That is precisely what we are aiming at doing.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

QUESTION.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are both too many interjections and too much audible conversation in the chamber at present. The Chair has great difficulty in hearing Senator Jones. I ask Senator Jones to commence his question again.

—Thank you, Mr President, for your protection. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jones obviously has no knowledge of the procedures of a Premiers Conference. Whilst the Commonwealth is calling the Conference specifically with relation to a wages freeze, of course it would be willing to hear submissions from Premiers on other matters. I make perfectly clear what I said yesterday. I said that the constitutional power over prices lies with the six States. In the past the people of Australia have refused to give to the Commonwealth power over prices.
—You could do it if you wanted to, you constitutional dope.
—Order! Senator Evans, I did hear that remark which was unparliamentary. I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw the expression 'constitutional dope'.
—Order! Senator Evans, I ask you to withdraw that remark unconditionally.
—I withdraw it unconditionally.

—I repeat that I can quite understand why members of the Opposition want to interject-to try not to have the facts of the matter made available to the public of Australia. I repeat emphatically-each of the Premiers has endorsed this-that every State Premier has total constitutional power over prices within his State. If any Premier today within his State wants to do so--
—So does the Commonwealth, under section 51 (xx) of the Constitution.

—Members of the Opposition think so much of Senator Evans's knowledge of constitutional law that Mr Hayden is on his knees begging Mr Wran to come here to be the shadow Attorney-General. There could not be a greater condemnation of this brain-fevered bird who yapity, yapity yaps every day. Fancy this man coming here and telling us that he has some knowledge of constitutional law, when his leader has disowned him publicly! Mr Hayden is down on his knees pleading to Mr Wran to come along to be the shadow Attorney-General . So let us have none of that kind of nonsense at all; let Senator Evans retreat into his little corner and light a candle, because he would need it.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me repeat the situation: If, indeed, the Premiers want to impose prices control within their States they have full and constitutional power to do so. But the Commonwealth takes the view that profitability is certainly not an ingredient of prices today, because it is unprofitability which is producing unemployment; that the main ingredient of prices today is the upsurge in wages; and that the primary task of a Premiers Conference would be to look for a wages freeze. Today's Australian Financial Review has made that abundantly clear. Let the Labor Party reject that. Let it reject again its leader of the past, who has made clear the relationship between inflation and unemployment. I repeat: If the Premiers want to do something about prices they can do so now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Government has repeatedly made it clear that it strongly supports the right of Israel to exist in peace within secure and recognised frontiers. I am sure that this view is overwhelmingly supported in Australia, but no comparably clear statement has been made about our attitude to the Palestinians. Does the Minister agree that a key element in any lasting solution of the problems in this troubled region lies in a fair solution of the problem of the Palestinians and their descendants who lived within the boundaries of the mandated territory of Palestine when it was partitioned by the United Nations in 1948? What is the attitude of the Government to the rights of these Palestinians to a homeland in Palestine-that is, the area between the River Jordan and the sea? What is the attitude of the Government towards the sovereignty of Jerusalem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Government believes that a resolution of the Palestinian issue is central to the future stability and peace of the Middle East and the long term security of all states in the region. The Government believes that a comprehensive settlement of Middle East problems should be based on the principles expressed in United Nations Security Council resolution 242: That is, recognition of the right of Israel and other states in the area to live in peace within secure and recognised boundaries and withdrawal of Israel from territories captured in 1967. Such a comprehensive settlement should also be based on recognition of the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people, including their right to a homeland alongside Israel, with the corresponding responsibility to live in peace with their neighbours, together with the right to participate directly in decisions affecting their future.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has welcomed and supported President Reagan's initiative, which seeks to reconcile Israel's legitimate security rights with the legitimate rights of the Palestinians and to bring the parties involved into direct negotiations. It is, as well, pleased to note that the recent Arab proposals from the summit meeting at Fez also support the goal of a negotiated settlement. The major significance of these initiatives, as well as of the Venice declaration of the European Council in 1980, is that while they contain specific proposals which may not be acceptable to one or other of the parties, in general terms they all favour a negotiated settlement. The Australian Government believes that the very fact that negotiations are envisaged as an essential element if a settlement is to be attained makes it inappropriate for Australia to pronounce on the specific terms for such a settlement. It believes that these should be negotiated directly by the parties principal to the dispute.

On the matter of Jerusalem, Australia, along with many other governments, has supported long-standing United Nations resolutions calling for an international regime for the city with appropriate protection for the holy places. However, as the question that has been raised today implies, the status of Jerusalem is one of the most sensitive matters in dispute between the parties to the Middle East conflict. It is difficult to envisage that the comprehensive political settlement that we all hope for in the Middle East would not, among other things , address the question of the status to be given to the city of Jerusalem. The Australian Government believes that whatever should be agreed for Jerusalem should give adequate protection for access to the holy places.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question inevitably is directed to Senator Sir John Carrick as Leader of the Government in the Senate but it relates to his speciality of economics, not to his other speciality of constitutional law. Is it the case that he said in answer to a question from Senator Button earlier today that the Australian economy had gone into recession because of a fall in export sales? Is he aware that in the first four months of this financial year, from July to October-I quote from figures from the Parliamentary Library released this week- export sales totalled $7,036m, compared with $6,122m in the same period last year; that is to say, there was a very substantial increase both in dollar and real terms, an increase which is reflected in any other way he chooses to calculate the change this year compared with last year? Is the Leader of the Government, any more than the Prime Minister, capable of lying straight in bed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I were convinced before of Senator Evans's capacity in either economics or law, I have the proof now. It is no wonder that Mr Hayden 's judgment is as it is; it is one judgment with which I concur. The fact of the matter is that Australia's export industry is based upon two main elements. It is based upon the mining and extracting industry and the farming industry which, on the most recent figures, make up something like 90 per cent of our export industry. Everybody knows that volume and price of minerals have fallen off. Hardly a day goes by without there being a story to the effect that a country such as Japan has cut back on its imports of minerals. Hardly a day goes by without our hearing the same basic story about bauxite, alumina or aluminium. The fact that the honourable senator is taking a narrow figure of a particular kind does not refute the situation. I would have thought that he also would have known that the farming community itself is facing for the future an enormous problem. With the exception of about one State, it is facing the virtual collapse of its cereal crops. It is also facing lowering prices, particularly in respect of beef, on world markets. Australia's exports in quantity and in price have declined substantially and that depressive factor is primarily responsible for Australia's inability to employ.

ANSWER.PARA: All the figures in the world quoted from some statistical situation cannot get away from the fact that the world is in absolute glut in respect of iron ore, that in fact the free world has an excess of something like 100 million tonnes in steel making capacity and an inability to sell steel. There is, of course, the clear evidence of the problem at the Portland alumina smelter. There is the clear evidence of smelters all around the place incapable of being put into production because there is no demand. That is absolutely elementary. We see evidence of that day after day. It is also elementary to look at the agricultural products. I repeat that the fundamental reason for Australia's recession is that overseas countries are not buying goods at reasonable prices from Australia in terms of the volume of goods and the prices they were paying for them before. Of course, they are not investing in Australia as readily as they were before. That is the basis of the recession.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The hollow and superficial response by the Fraser Government to Australia's economic collapse.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose this is recycling a matter that has been discussed on a number of occasions in the Senate; but, in a sense, I want to deal with the particular responses of the Government in the last week which have taken the form of a proposed wage pause that has been described by a number of newspaper editorials and other commentators as a stunt and a gimmick. I say at the outset that, when one looks at this Government's record, there is reason for that scepticism. When one looks at its ill fated wage-price freeze of 1977 or the resources boom of 1980 which was to be a cure for unemployment in Australia-creating tens of thousands of jobs, in the words of the Treasurer (Mr Howard)-one sees that the suggestion ought to be made to the Government that with this response it is not responding in any real sense to the real challenge which faces Australia's economy at present. Rather, there is a lapse, to use Mr Michael Baume's words, into appearing to be doing something about unemployment. That is the essence of the recent announcement of the Government. What we have, of course, is a mish mash of hastily drafted concepts.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply summarise the Government's proposition announced by the Acting Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, on Monday in these terms: First of all, we will freeze Public Service wages for one year. That will save an estimated $700m. We will use that money to create jobs. Those jobs will presumably be created in the public sector because I do not see how public servants' money can be used to create jobs in the private sector. If we create jobs in the public sector with this money it is flying in the face of everything this Government has said in the seven years it has been in office. Then, in addition to freezing wages in the public sector, we will hope that the private sector will follow suit. In respect of those persons in the community whose incomes are unable to be controlled by any Government mechanism-that is, professional income earners and so on-we will again hope that they will follow suit and that there will be some freeze on their wages. At the end of that process, we will see what happens. If nothing happens, we can blame the State Governments, overseas factors, trade unions or the Public Service. That is the traditional abandonment of intellectual responsibility in which this Government always indulges in the face of the continued failure of its policies.

I make the point at the beginning that, when we talk about lowering incomes in real terms, we are talking about the incomes of thousands of Australian families who are concerned about the day to day problems of buying food and clothing and of paying off mortgages at a time when interest rates in this country are higher than they have ever been. So we should not talk lightly about lowering incomes. We should look at it in the context of overall government strategy and recognise its real importance-the lowering of incomes to Australian families. In singling out wages as the cause of all the unemployment problems which this country now faces, and to a lesser extent overseas factors, the Government is indulging in simple minded sloganeering, an over-simplification of very difficult problems. I do not retreat from the fact that both wages and overseas factors are relevant to the competitive position of Australia. They are also relevant to unemployment but they must be seen in the context of a wide range of factors that are relevant to employment.

This Government has to face up to the fact that there has been a long term decline in manufacturing employment in Australia. It is sometimes said that manufacturing is the major employment area, but that is no longer so. There has been a decline of 7 per cent in manufacturing employment since 1965. New jobs have been created in Australia, but in manufacturing industry there has been a continual decline in the number of people employed. The Government cannot say in 1982 that wages are responsible for the collapse of the Australian steel industry. They are not. It cannot say that the advance of technology in industry has not been a factor in unemployment in Australia. Of course it has. The Government's own committee, the Myers Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia, found that. What did the Government do with that committee' s report? It put it in a pigeon-hole. We have not heard of it since it was published.

Another factor which is relevant to employment is the wide age spread of people who are involved in employment in Australia from 16 to 65. In Japan and other countries with much lower levels of unemployment the spread in the work force is from about age 20 to about age 60 at the most. These are long term considerations relating to declining employment in Australia. Of course the more immediate things which have produced the dramatic decline in employment in Australia are the collapse of consumer demand, the total collapse of consumer confidence to spend money and, of course, the collapse of the resources boom which was heralded in 1980, prior to the last election, as being the saviour of Australia's employment problems.

I argue to the Senate that the problems of the Australian economy are profound. If one seeks to say that all those problems are caused by one factor, namely wages, one runs into the danger described, I think, quite graphically by an American Congressman when he said: 'You run the danger that the light at the end of the tunnel will turn out to be an oncoming train'. That is the position with this Government. The light at the end of the tunnel about which Mr Anthony spoke on Monday could well turn out to be an oncoming train. What happens at the end of the wages pause? We all know what happens at the end of wages pauses in Australia. There is an explosion of wage demands. But what happens if, at the end of the wages pause, there is no visible effect on the unemployment situation in Australia? What does one say then? One says exactly the same as one said about the resources boom which was to produce thousands and thousands of jobs. All sorts of factors intervened and it went away. That is what might happen here , and it is a matter about which I wish to caution the Government in relation to its suggested strategy.

We have to face up to the fact that Australia, in 1982, has a negative growth rate. That is revealed in the Budget Papers. Australia is one of the few countries-perhaps the only country other than Britain-of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development which have a negative growth rate. It is certainly the only country in the OECD which has had the twin successes of achieving high levels of inflation and unemployment at the same time. Indeed, no other country in the Western world has succeeded in having at the same time high levels of inflation and of unemployment. Some countries have high inflation and low unemployment, but no other country in the OECD has achieved, at the same time, anything like the same levels of inflation and unemployment.

Another point to remember is that Australia has the highest interest rates of any country of the OECD. Also, this Government has no wages policy. That is a very important factor to bear in mind when considering what is wrong with this country at this time. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Mr Anthony's statement of Monday sought to lay the blame for Australia's economic troubles on the dramatic wage rate increases of recent times. I wish to make a few points about that. At the very best we have to make a proper assessment of what has happened in relation to wages in Australia on a truly annual basis rather than on the basis of the last six months. The figures Mr Anthony has used indicate a tendency for wage increase rates to fall in the last six months, from a high point in March 1982. If the Government had any sense of policy consistency it should have taken action in March 1982, or earlier, to deal with the wage rate explosion which occurred in the final quarter of 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: The present wage freeze is indicative of total ad hockery in this regard. In fact, the Government's own Budget Papers show that real wage increases occurred in December 1981 and in the first quarter of 1982. I assert that they all occurred because of the abandonment by the Government in mid-1981 of any pretensions to a wages policy and a centralised wage fixation system. When, in July of 1981, wage indexation went out the window the wages explosion developed and many unions caught up, in six months, what they had lost since this Government came to power. That was the economic disaster for this country. As Mr Peacock, a Minister in the present Government put it, this Government has no wages policy. That is what he said at the time.

I do not assert for a moment that wages are not of some significance in terms of our competitive position and of employment, but the figures used by Mr Anthony to show increases in real wages are from the Bureau of Statistics average weekly earnings series-by no means an unchallenged source. Indeed, serious doubts have been cast upon it. Senator Tate earlier today cast doubts upon it in a question which he put to Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. The National Institute of Labour Studies Incorporated, of Flinders University, publisher of the authoritative Australian Bulletin of Labour, takes serious issue with the ABS figures. It points out that the average weekly earnings series is a poor measure of wages growth during a period when labour is being shed and the composition of the employed work force is changing. The ABS figures measure wages growth on average but do not take into account the fact that lower paid workers are dropping into the unemployment pool and their lower wages are no longer being taken into account in assessing the average. It points out also that other, better, guides could be adopted. The Institute argues that only a 13 per cent increase in earnings growth has occurred over the last 12 months; that, given the current 12.4 per cent rate of inflation, wages in Australia have followed the OECD pattern exactly-they have done little more than keep pace with inflation. They have not increased to anything like the extent which the present government, by plucking odd figures out of the air, claims.

There is a great deal of talk about wages becoming so high that productivity and profits are affected. Mr Anthony and Senator Sir John Carrick would like to say that this is the reason we are in economic trouble, that the sole problem is wages. But let us look at the Government's own figures. I invite honourable senators who are concerned to understand this matter to look at the Government's own figures at page 28 of Budget Paper No. 1 for 1982-83. That table shows that real unit labour costs measured 108 in the index in 1976-77. This figure is derived from dividing average weekly labour costs by average labour productivity . For the second half of 1981-82 the figure is exactly the same, 108. An examination of the period 1976 to 1982 reveals that real unit labour costs have not changed significantly over the period. In other words, labour costs relatively no more than it did in 1976 in terms of wage costs and productivity. The real reason that jobs are being lost in Australia is that demand is low and consumers have no confidence. Demand is low because of restrictive Government policies.

In the time available I want to deal with the mythology of increasing wage rates and unemployment. I have said, and I repeat, that I do not say that there is no relationship between the two-there is. I think there is a much stronger relationship between claims for a 35-hour week and unemployment, which should be taken account of by the unions. What has happened in this country, of course, is that the real wages of income groups below the average did not increase between 1976 and 1981. The labour resources study to which I referred goes to August 1981, but I think the figures are still very relevant to this point. What it shows is that a person in a category of above average weekly earnings had a significant increase in real wages between 1976 and 1981, but a person on average weekly earnings had a minus 1.2 per cent real increase during that period. A person on below average weekly earnings, for example on the bottom salary level, had a minus 11.4 percent increase during that period. What I am saying is that we cannot look at the whole picture and just say that wages have increased. Wages have increased in real terms for the wealthy; they have not increased in real terms for the low income earners. I seek leave to incorporate that table in Hansard.
