TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened in this country in the last seven years is that the burden of taxation has shifted from the wealthy section of the community to the poorer section of the community and the burden of income has shifted in favour of the wealthy section as against the poorer section. That is what that table shows. When we talk about average weekly earnings we must look at who is below the average. That is where the unemployment is and that is where wage increases have not kept pace with inflation. It is the higher groups whose wages have gone up, but the benefits have gone through tax. This contributes to lower demand because the propensity is for lower income earners to spend more. I ask honourable senators to look at that table as proof of what I have been trying to advance by way of argument.

SPEECH.PARA: My argument is that in the longer term the relationship between increasing real wages and unemployment is very doubtful. I invite honourable senators who are concerned and interested in this subject matter to read discussion paper No. 47 of May 1982 by Dr Bob Gregory of the Australian National University Centre for Economic Policy Research. I summarise his conclusion, which is documented in the paper. Dr Gregory said:
It is obvious that there is no stable relationship between wage increases and the level of unemployment.

He charts that in a graph showing wage increases going up and the level of unemployment going in a different direction. I invite honourable senators to look at that paper because it is a very important and thoughtful paper on the question of the relationship between wages and unemployment. Low labour demand is caused by low demand for output and the way to increase output is to stimulate demand by putting money into the hands of more people. I notice the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) nodding his head about this. He prefers to believe the simple slogan that Australia's problems are due to wages and overseas factors. It is a beaut political slogan for the Government to be able to say that. What I have tried to do is analyse whether or not it is right.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks the economic situation of this country is too serious now for us to play politics of the old poll, Malcolm Fraser kind. One cannot go on finding glib political solutions to an enormously difficult economic situation. If one goes on trying to find glib political solutions one will run out of steam after six months or nine months and one will be no further forward in terms of tackling the real problems. That is a very real danger which I fear regarding this Government's purported solutions to this country's current economic difficulties. They are not simple problems and there are no simple solutions. A lot of hard facts will have to be faced up to. It is no good facing up to hard facts and difficult times by mouthing simple-minded cliches and slogans about the nature of the problems which this country faces. I commend these matters to serious thought in the Senate rather than sloganeering of a kind which will no longer work for this country and which will send us further and further down the hit parade of the Organisation of Economic Co-operation and Development countries in terms of our standard of living and our industrial performance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Notwithstanding the somewhat extravagant language of the matter of public importance that has been proposed today, the Government welcomes the opportunity of discussing the announcement made last Monday in regard to a wages freeze or pause being embarked upon by the Government at the present time. Clearly, there are difficulties in implementing any kind of incomes freeze or pause at a time when the Federal Government does not possess the constitutional power to deal effectively with these matters at all levels within the States. Clearly, there is a need for the co-operation of the States at all levels working with the Federal Government to achieve a reasonable approach in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button in his remarks acknowledged quite clearly to us all that he regards I think as a critical factor the effects of wages upon the community and upon the economic development of Australia. I would like to develop that theme a little more as this debate proceeds today. First of all, I think we should address our minds to one or two of the background questions that have existed in this country for some time. There can be no question that for some years Australia has been insulated from the world recession by strong growth that has been directly related to our own mineral and other capital development projects. During the last few years we have seen very high levels of unemployment in the United Kingdom. For instance, I believe that in the last three years that level has been in the order of 13 per cent. In Canada it has been over 12 per cent and in the United States of America over 10 per cent. This is compared in recent times with an unemployment rate in this country of around 6 per cent. Clearly Australia has been doing relatively well. Surely that is no sign of economic collapse as has been alluded to by the Opposition in its matter of public importance. I will deal with the Government's response to this matter at a later stage.

Let us go a little further to discover some of the real points at issue in this debate. The world recession was brought about, generally speaking, by a decline in demand by the Western world and particularly for products of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries on world markets. This, of course, has been brought about over a long period through gradual change in the shifts of economic power between the Western nations and the East Asian bloc. Clearly, this has affected our position insofar as we supply minerals and other raw materials to the countries that are dealing in this kind of manufacturing throughout the world. Consequently there has been a very severe effect and in more recent times, as the recession has gathered pace overseas, a downturn in our capacity to sell our products on world markets. Incomes and activity were declining from external causes causing not only unemployment in this country but also reduced, I believe, the level of incomes in this country in real terms.

One of the contributing factors-again Senator Button does not deny the existence of this fact-is that there has been a very significant rise in incomes in this country. It is quite clear that over time incomes have outstripped the rate of inflation and there have been real increases in wages in recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Upper incomes, not lower incomes.

—I will come to that point in a moment. There was not only the question of direct labour rates but also the question of workmen's conditions generally. We know of the wage package that was settled by the metal trades with the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and other metal workers unions only 12 months ago. This resulted in an overall net increase in labour costs of the order of 22 per cent. That entailed not just pure raw wage increases but workers' conditions were somewhat severely affected by the reduction of the working week. Other things were involved in that package also which led to a significant rise in labour costs. With the rises in labour costs come further increases in things such as workers compensation insurance costs and other matters that relate directly to the employment of individuals. We are talking about not only labour costs or wage costs but the whole gamut of labour costs relating to wages, salaries and other incomes which is at question here. This is a matter about which Senator Button seeks to mislead us in the Senate today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button has limited his argument to the area of wages and argues that it is only those at the lower end of the wages scale who have suffered. We have to acknowledge that, unfortunately, those at the lower end of the wages scale have, in fact, not done as well as those at the upper levels. One of the reasons-the chief reason probably-why that is so is the existence of wage indexation as it applied from 1975 until 1981. That produced a situation where those automatically at the bottom end of the wages structure were not going to be compensated so well as those at the upper end and that is a direct result of the Australian Labor Party policy which was put in place in 1975 by the then Labor Government. It is a matter which has been argued against year after year by this Government in various wage tribunals. That is a truth. It relates directly to the point raised by Senator Button which cannot be accepted as a truth in this matter. On both those points Senator Button's argument falls to the ground.

Let us turn to one or two other matters relating to the question of wage costs. Senator Button rightly drew our attention to the fact that there have been changes in the wage structure within Australia. He pointed out that in 1976 the index-he chose to quote from the Budget Papers; I have not had time to check them, but I assume he is correct-applying in 1976 was 108. He made the point that the index applying in 1982 is 108; in other words, there has been no change in real unit labour costs in the last six years. What he did not tell us was that in December 1976 there was a 17 1/2 per cent devaluation of the currency. The effect of that on our competitive structure overseas at that time was enormous. We have a clear example of that in the boost which it brought to our exports during the subsequent years from 1977 to 1981. Senator Button failed to mention those points. Instead he chose to make narrow debating points by quoting such authorities in order to draw our attention away from the real issues which are before us in this debate.

In this time of very real concern, when there is quite clearly rising unemployment resulting from a lack of product demand overseas for our produce and when there has been a rapid fall in our competitive position brought about by rising labour costs-I use that generic term, not just the narrow one of wages and/or other incomes but the associated costs as well-we need to address clearly the fundamental problems. How can Senator Button or any Opposition honourable senator claim today that that fundamental approach to which this Government is endeavouring to bring some conclusion is in some way superficial or hollow, as the terms of the matter of public importance indicate? One would have thought that Senator Evans, in his usual extravagant way, had written the words of the motion. Perhaps the Australian Labor Party has resorted to using its advertising agents to word motions for debate in this place. It is clear that these are fundamental issues. They are the ones which this Government is seeking to attack . The problems of dealing with those issues are enormous. We know that there are constitutional difficulties. We know that there are difficulties in dealing with the States, particularly those of different political complexions. Those matters have emerged in the last few days.

This Government has accepted that challenge and is calling a Premiers Conference to bring the Premiers together to discuss the incomes of public employees, not only those who are employed by the Commonwealth, but also those who are employed at the State and local government levels. By virtue of the influence which the States have in their own areas, the Government is endeavouring to bring those in the private arena into an agreement whereby incomes can be further controlled. This is an operation designed to bring consensus in Australian society-not division. There is clearly an opportunity and a challenge for this country to grasp the fundamental issues, face them and determine jointly a policy which will achieve the desired end. Clearly, this is the issue which is before us and this Government. It is an issue which this Government had the courage to grasp and was put down in a clear and unequivocal statement by the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) last week.

There is no way in which we can easily buy ourselves out of trouble. It is true that some Premiers see it that way. I will deal with those matters a little later. Firstly, I will round off the major point. None of us in this country can exist unless we establish a more competitive base for our industry. Our whole industrial base-whether it be the tertiary sector, the secondary sector or whatever-revolves around the question of our being able to meet import competition or alternatively being able to sell goods produced in this country on the world markets. I wish to quote from the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review which clearly spells out the impacts on Australians at all levels of not facing up to these fundamental truths. The editorial stated:

There is no way city populations-and that means everybody, not just the blue collar union members-can continue to increase their real incomes in the face of the situation facing Australia in 1983. One way or another, belt-tightening is inevitable. If it isn't imposed by a Government wages freeze it will be imposed by a collapse in employment as the jobless percentage heads into double figures and wages claims disappear as employees cling with increasing desperation to their existing jobs.

I believe that sums up in very few words exactly where the Government stands on this matter. The Government does not discard its responsibilities. Rather it grasps them and is prepared to deal with the significant political and legal questions that surround these matters. The initiatives that will be put forward at the Premiers Conference on 7 December involve a 12-month pause on all wages. Preferably the Commonwealth and the States will act together to legislate for a pause in award wages in the public and private sectors. Alternatively, they could act together to impose a pause in the public sector and seek, through tribunals and other means, to have a pause also implemented in the private sector.

If this proposal were to be accepted it would be on the basis that there would not be any question of a following catch-up for wage increases forgone during that period. The point to which Senator Button drew our attention-that is, a subsequent explosion after a period of pause-is clearly contemplated by the Government in putting forward its proposition. There will be considerable savings to the Commonwealth and State governments. This has been detailed by the Acting Prime Minister in his statement. The savings will amount to some $700m. The Commonwealth has in mind that those savings achieved by governments as a result of the pause should be applied to employment related activities. The Commonwealth will contribute a substantial part of that expenditure but very substantial savings to State and local governments will also result. It will be up to those participating States to deal with their savings in various ways. Of course, it will be up to the Federal Government to work in relation to that also .

I believe this is a very significant step in the direction of controlling the flood of wage claims which are coming forward at this time and it will be very significant in controlling the rise in the rate of inflation in this country. It is clear that the only way to generate further investment in this economy on the part of business is to return business to a more profitable situation. Clearly, that is related to keeping wage levels under resonable controls. Consequently, we will be continuing to address that.

I think we should now turn to other things this Government has been doing over the last three months, after facing up to its real responsibilities which became evident in the July period. In August the Government introduced a Budget the chief objective of which was to provide some reduction in costs, particularly in government charges, by reducing income tax in order to support families who were in need, especially in relation to the problems they face with interest payments and, of course, the rising level of general inflation. We have seen the Government measures that have already been established. The home loan interest rebate subsidy, which applied from 1 November, has been introduced. There has been a stepping up in the amount of the family allowance. The rate of tax applicable to incomes under about $17,000 or $18,000 has been generally reduced from 32 per cent to 30 per cent. The amount has been increased from around $4, 200 to around $4,600.

After taking into account increases in sales taxes which also flowed from the Budget, net returns to families of people on average weekly earnings total about $17 a week. That is a very significant contribution to the welfare of families in this most difficult time and, clearly, it is related to the kind of approach which this Government has adopted. It is to be hoped that that kind of benefit, flowing directly from the Federal Government, will be a force for the moderation of wage pressures in this coming period.

Consequently, the approach we have now adopted, leading towards a pause in wage costs and pressures, is directly related to that and seeks to lessen the blow on familites of the implementation of this pause over the next 12 months. Clearly it is an attempt by this Government to maintain reasonable living standards at the expense of the finances of the Commonwealth while asking the people of this nation to restrain their attempts to seek higher and higher wages at the expense of our competitive position on world markets. That integrated approach, together with other measures in which I know Senator Siddons is interested, such as the depreciation package back in July which will be very significant in generating further investment in this community and thereby creating more and more jobs, has been made with the same objective clearly in view. It has been made to lessen the pressure on business caused by the effects of taxation and inflation and to encourage business to obtain more effective and updated equipment to enable it to sell goods more effectively and efficiently and with better results on world markets.

That is not an ad hoc approach. It is certainly not a hollow approach to the problems of this nation. It is a reasoned, integrated, rational approach to the problems that Australia faces. It is an approach aimed at creating jobs in a situation in which clearly we are facing tremendous pressures. That approach has been well thought out. It has been developed with consensus in view. It is aimed towards producing a satisfactory result at the Premiers Conference on 7 December . To call it gimmickry is not to face up to the real issues, and this is the hardest thing to do in this country. While we have the Neville Wrans going around seeking quick answers by raising protection barriers all over the place with no regard to the real issues, we can expect this kind of narrow, if you like, 'head-in-the-sand' approach from the ALP which does not deserve to be in any form of government while it adopts that sort of approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1976 we were told by the Government that the essential thing was to bear down on inflation and unemployment would cure itself. After seven years of Fraserism, after seven years of bearing down on inflation, inflation has in fact gone up from 12.1 per cent to 12.3 per cent and unemployment has more than doubled. When this Government came into office fewer than a quarter of a million people were unemployed. There are now more than half a million. The economy is collapsing, as this matter of public importance states. It is collapsing because aggregate output is actually contracting for the first time since 1961 and jobs are being lost at the rate of 1,000 a day. What Senator Sir John Carrick euphemistically calls 'disemployment' means people being sacked at the rate of a thousand a day. In nearly seven years from 1976 to the present we have been promised and Government Ministers have forecast an investment-led recovery, a consumer-led recovery, an export-led recovery and a resource boom-led recovery. There have been promises of tax cuts and realities of tax increases. What we have seen is not a coherent policy but a succession of political stunts, the latest of which is the proposal off the top of the prime ministerial head last weekend for a pay pause.

SPEECH.PARA: The Sydney Morning Herald yesterday saw fit to write a major editorial on this latest Government stunt. I will quote extracts from that editorial in the knowledge, and I trust the knowledge shared by most Australians, that the Sydney Morning Herald is, to say the least, not a paper with a traditional record of opposition to conservative governments. Indeed, only once in living memory has it actually supported the Australian Labor Party, and that was more than 20 years ago. This is what the Sydney Morning Herald said about this latest stunt- the pay pause:
At last the Federal Government is worried about unemployment and is willing to act. After about five months of decision-making paralysis caused by pre-election jitters, action is welcome.
It continues:

And the special Premiers' Conference to discuss a 12-month wage freeze announced by Mr Anthony last night has a distinct smell of panic about it. Moreover, the proposal also smells of gimmickry and buck-passing.
This was not said by Bill Hayden; this was not said by Bob Hawke; this is the Sydney Morning Herald's assessment of the Government's pay pause policy. The editorial continued:

The speed with which the wage-freeze idea has surfaced bears testimony to its panic-induced and ill-considered nature. A Government which is notorious for its ponderous decision-making-which took three months to resolve a simple dispute over the SRD release for housing-has come up with a major new plank in its economic strategy within little more than a week.
This is the Sydney Morning Herald's assessment. It continued:

Until the recent passing of a few carefully calculated dates in Mr Fraser's diary, the Government's plan was cynically to anticipate rising unemployment, rather than actually to tackle it. Its new-found sense of urgency seems to be motivated by political, rather than economic or social, concerns.
The Sydney Morning Herald continued:

There is but one precedent for the course the Government has now embarked upon: the ill-considered and short-lived wage-and-price freeze cooked up overnight at the Premiers' Conference of April, 1977. The epitaph of the Government's latest brainstorm can be written in advance from the orthodoxy of the Government's own Treasurers and economic advisers-

This is not the assessment of a Labor Premier. This is not the assessment of Bill Hayden. It is the editorial assessment of the Sydney Morning Herald, one of the most conservative newspapers in the country. It said:
The gimmickry in the Government's plan is evident from the novel proposal to divert the savings from the Public Service pay freeze . . .
The buck-passing in the Government's plan is both direct and indirect . . .

The second element of buck-passing in the wage-freeze proposal is a little more subtle. By turning the debate about rising unemployment into a debate about wage claims, the Government has focused attention on one aspect of the problem, but drawn attention away from other aspects. In the process it has transferred responsibility for the failure of economic management away from itself and onto the unions.

I stress again that all those comments were made in yesterday's editorial of the Sydney Morning Herald. The latest of this succession of stunts, the latest gimmick, is intended to divert public attention from the failure of seven years of Fraserism and the absence of any economic strategy in the August Budget. The true measure of failure of this Government is the simple fact that, after seven years of rhetoric about bearing down on inflation, inflation has gone up and the number of people unemployed has more than doubled. It is true that unemployment is high in many countries but only Australia-only the Fraser Government-has doubled unemployment and pushed up inflation simultaneously.

The response of the Government is to deny responsibility and to declare unconditional surrender to economic circumstances which it avows are beyond its control. The problem of the Australian economy, the Government says, is due entirely to world factors and wage demands by the unions. Even if the figure cited by the Government about wage increases were reliable-Senator Button has already demonstrated that they are not-who is responsible for that situation? Who is responsible for no wages policy over the last 18 months? I suppose that we could blame the Prince of Wales or the Princess Diana, because in May 1981 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) was more interested in jumping on a jet to attend the royal wedding than he was in doing his job as Prime Minister of this country. The Government in the middle of 1981 abandoned any attempt at government involvement in a wages policy and said: 'Let market forces prevail, let us decentralise the wage system and let governments keep out of it'. The Government can hardly complain if, as a consequence of that abdication of responsibility, wages increased, especially as the unions had been subjected to a 12-month long harangue, principally from people such as Senator Carrick, about the resources boom and the untold riches the resources boom was about to deliver to this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rundle.

—As Senator Sibraa reminds me, Senator Carrick said that Rundle would be producing 50,000 barrels a day by 1985 and was the greatest thing that Australia had discovered since Bass Strait. Untold riches would be delivered by the resources boom, Government spokesmen told us, again for political reasons. The Government can scarcely complain or expect to be taken seriously when it does complain if, as a result of that reckless talking-up of the resources boom and the abdication of responsibility when the Prime Minister jumped on a jet to go the royal wedding, there were in those sectors of industry where there was a capacity to pay wage demands which flowed on to a significant extent to other sectors. 'We are in a mess', the Government says, 'and there is nothing we can do about it except wait for world conditions to improve, for the inevitable upturn to come, and then we can take advantage of it'. The Labor Party absolutely rejects that negativism and that confession of failure.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from diverting attention from the Government's long-standing failures, the wages pause is an attempt to conceal the fact that there was no economic strategy in the 1982 Budget. This latest stunt is an attempt to compensate for the absence of strategy or to cover up for it. Senator Carrick supplements the Government's cop-out policy with a series of untrue assertions, of which we have had at least four in the last week. On 11 November, in characteristic style, he said: 'Well, it does not matter how bad this Government is; the Labor Government which existed almost a decade ago was worse'. Even if that was true it is, of course, not a respectable excuse for this Government. But it is not true. Senator Carrick backs it up with an untrue assertion that when Labor left government inflation was running at 17 1/2 per cent. It is a false claim which he has made many times. In fact, as anyone who cares to look at the statistics will see, when Labor actually left government the annual inflation rate was 12.1 per cent-admittedly temporarily depressed because of a blip. It was 14 per cent at the end of the year. But when Labor actually left government it was 12.1 per cent. It is now 12.3 per cent.

Yesterday Senator Carrick said that real wages had fallen in most or all of the countries in the Ogranisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. He was forced to amend that today, like a Stalinist revising Hansard, to say: 'In all other OECD countries there have been calls to moderate excessive wage demands'. Today he said that the Australian recession had been caused by a decline in exports, notwithstanding the fact that in the first four months of this financial year, when the economy had really taken a nosedive, exports in real terms were higher than they were in the same four months of 1981. Today when he really got carried away he said that in the 1930s inflation was negative and interest rates also were negative. That is a novel proposition. The only way one can make sense of that statement is to assume that people paid considerable amounts to banks for storing their money. Senator Carrick said that interest rates were negative in the 1930s and inflation also was negative. It is true that for a year or two inflation was negative; interest rates were never negative. Poor Senator Carrick; he is so confused. I guess that his inability to count is a function of spending too many years picking up brown paper bags full of money without knowing how much was in them.

The latest stunt produced by this Government is underpinned or reinforced by an appeal to fairness-to spread the inevitable costs of this recession on an equitable basis throughout the community. If the Government really wants to do that, there is a simple and certain way of doing it: Increase unemployment benefits. I do not want to dwell on that matter. The campaign for fairness is led by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony)-the man who granted himself a 4 3/ 4 per cent government loan to buy one of the two houses he owns in Canberra, a loan 80 per cent of which has still not been repaid. If the Government really expects to be taken at all seriously, the prerequisite to gaining any moral credibility, any moral authority at all, is for the Prime Minister to instruct his deputy to repay that 4 3/4 per cent loan. It has been a matter of public knowledge for six months that he has it and nothing has been done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard it said today that the problems of the country are being caused by pre-election jitters. I suggest that the only reason there have been such jitters, if there have been, is that members of the Australian Labor Party have been talking about an election for so long. Obviously they wanted an election at this time. Mr Hayden has been talking about it consistently. As I recall, last week Senator Gietzelt was talking in this very place about an election and wanting to know when it was to be held. The rest of us know that it will be held at the end of next year. The destabilising effect that that sort of talk has is harmful. We have heard quotes from the editorial in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald about the proposal for a wages freeze. I can quote from the Hobart Mercury of 28 October comments on the Labor Party's proposals. Its editorial stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Federal Opposition, Mr Hayden, has been in the happy political position of being able to blame Government policies for rising inflation and unemployment without having the onerous task of suggesting better alternatives. This tactic stirs-up anti-Government feeling and gives the ALP and Mr Hayden the superficial appearance of being economic sages.
The editorial continued:

It also increases the public perception of doom and gloom. And lack of confidence is dangerous and often self-defeating. It can sabotage genuine efforts to try to contribute constructively towards getting Australia back on the path to prosperity . . .
On the surface, some of his suggestions appear sound. On closer analysis, however, they fail to impress because they are so remarkably similar to the disastrous Whitlam formulas.
The main ingredient is for the Federal Government to try to spend its way out of trouble. With inflation already at 12.3 per cent, this seems a recipe for economic disaster.

It is all very well for Senator Button to suggest that this matter is more serious than playing politics. When one looks at the comments on the Labor Party 's proposals for solutions to the economic problems, we know who is doing just that. As Senator Button has said, there are a number of reasons for the difficulties which exist at present. We have heard about the depressed level of international economic activity and the problem of domestic prices being out of line with those of our competitors, making it difficult for us to compete in overseas markets. No doubt there is a need to contain costs, to sustain investment and to improve productivity so that we are better able to compete.

Of course, one of the factors in higher local prices is the level of wages. It is worth looking at the growth in wages for the 12 months to September of this year. Ordinary time earnings for full time employed adults increased by 17.1 per cent and total earnings of all persons by 15.7 per cent. Let us look at the increased earnings in some other countries: For the United States of America for the 12 months to August of this year, 7.2 per cent; for Japan to July of this year, 0.6 per cent; for the Federal Republic of Germany to April of this year, 5 per cent; for the United Kingdom to August of this year, 10 per cent; for Canada to June of this year, 11.6 per cent. The average increase for members of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to May of this year was 10.7 per cent. With our high increases in wages we are, in fact, pricing ourselves out of competitiveness.

There is no doubt that the number of jobless in this country is too high-I cannot imagine anybody saying other than that. Until the end of 1981 the growth in the number of jobs in this country was satisfactory. For the two years to October 1981 the level of employment increased by 4.6 per cent-there was a growth of 281,300 jobs. That was significantly better than in 1979-80, when the level of employment increased by 2.3 per cent and 1980-81, when it increased by 2.7 per cent. In 1980-81 the level of unemployment was the lowest for four years . The international unemployment levels are also worth looking at: In Holland, in August of this year, the level was 12.9 per cent; in the United Kingdom, in September, it was 12.7 per cent; in Canada it was 12.2 per cent; in Italy it was 10.4 per cent; in the United States of America it was 10.1 per cent; in France it was 8.6 per cent; in West Germany it was 7.8 per cent; in Sweden it was 3.7 per cent; in Japan it was 2.4 per cent; and in Australia it is now 7.8 per cent.

Of course, it is interesting to compare the two sets of figures that I have mentioned with those in respect of Japan alone, where the growth in wages for the 12 months to July of this year was 0.6 per cent and the increase in the level of unemployment 2.4 per cent. Perhaps something is to be learned from that . We have heard cited, in the general debate on this question, figures in relation to the Depression. I suggest that, in fact, they are meaningless. So many significantly different factors are involved that they need to be looked at and some conclusions drawn in regard to them. In the 1930s the population of this country was 6.6 million; it is now 15 million. In August 1982, 6.4 million people, a number almost equal to that of the total population in the 1930s, had jobs. In June 1933 the level of unemployment was 22.4 per cent; some 481,044 people were out of work. This is to be compared with an unemployment level now of 7.8 per cent.

Other conclusions may be drawn from those figures. In 1933 the number of unemployed females was very low indeed; the number of unemployed males was very high. The figures now are different. This indicates quite clearly that the percentage of breadwinners out of work in 1933 was extremely high indeed. Of course, regrettably, now also a large number of breadwinners are out of work. But our young people make up the bulk of the unemployed.

Perhaps there are things in that regard that we can look at also. We can really ask whether the unions care whether anybody has a job. In particular we can ask whether they care whether young people have jobs. Would they agree to attempt to initiate a lower minimum wage for young people? A shop assistant at the age of 16 gets $112.50; at the age of 17, $135; and at the age of 18, $157.50 but frequently, at the same time, he or she receives a dismissal notice. What does that indicate? I think it indicates that young people of those ages are required to be paid more than employers regard as their value. Until that can be rectified there will continue to be significant problems with young unemployed people who cannot offer to employers skills that are regarded as reasonable in return for the wages that have to be paid. If unions were serious about this problem perhaps they would look very closely at it.

Of course, in the tourist industry the penalty rates keep a great number of people out of jobs which would otherwise be available. I do not think there is any doubt at all that most people agree that the tourist industry could be greatly benefited by penalty rates being abolished and a different structure of wages put in place so that more people could have jobs and could work at times which suited them. That would benefit the industry and this country. It is necessary for us to attract more tourists to encourage them to spend their money in Australia. The Weekend Australian of 16-17 October dealt with the matter of minimum wages. The article on that subject commenced:
There must be something terribly wrong with a minimum wage system that puts youngsters out of work the day they turn 18.
I think it is time that all of us had a look at that aspect of this mater.

The Government has done quite an amount in relation to helping young people who are out of work. Honourable senators will well recall some of the highlights of the Budget of 1982-83 in that regard. The manpower and training programs allocation was increased by 21 per cent to $254.7m, compared with $210.5m in the previous year. More than 252,000 people, representing an 18 per cent increase, can be assisted under the programs for this year. In respect of the Special Youth Employment Training Program an increased subsidy of $20 a week, raising the level from $55 a week to $75 a week, is to be paid. Under the program a number of young people have been able to gain experience and skills to offer an employer. A significant 33 per cent increase in the annual intake of students is envisaged.

The Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training has been adjusted and an extra $1m is to be devoted to technical and further education courses for the long term, young unemployed, to enable them to acquire skills with which to approach the market place. In the Budget provision was made for book allowances, equipment allowances and a number of other forms of assistance.

Also, an additional 25 per cent in funding was provided to permit expansion of the Community Youth Support Scheme, the number of projects under which will increase to 276. That is just a brief resume of the programs involved. It indicates that the Government has an awareness of the problems of young people in trying to obtain employment in these times. As I said earlier, it is a pity that others in the community-I have in mind the unions-have not the same attitude towards finding jobs for young people.

In Canberra, prior to the presentation of the Budget, a considerable increase in confidence occurred. The Budget indicated the Government's commitment to the growth and development of this Territory and a recognition of the problems that it has faced. The Master Builders Association of the Australian Capital Territory, in a Press release of 18 October, referred to a survey that it had undertaken before the 1982-83 Budget and said that in the next 12 months more than $70m worth of private sector capital works could begin in the national capital. However, union demands for substantial wage increases were making developers hesitate. The Association referred to demands for increases in excess of $65 a week for workers on some sites who were already receiving over $400 a week. The same Press release referred to some of the many bans that had been placed on construction sites in Canberra. The loss of confidence which that kind of action creates causes the private sector to wonder seriously whether it should invest, whether it can afford to go ahead with some of these projects. If it does not go ahead with them, fewer jobs will be available. In the Australian Capital Territory, where we have quite high unemployment-substantially amongst young people-it is particularly important that the unions accept some responsibility in the effort to make jobs available.

The union bans which exist in the Territory have had effects which go beyond deterring the private sector from proceeding with projects. I think it is worth looking at some of those bans. In spite of a two-year agreement in relation to industrial matters, there have been bans on the new Parliament House site. There have been bans at the Australian Defence Force Academy. Also, I ask: What about the police academy? There has also been a ban at the Grammar School site. Certainly, construction has not started but considerable jobs would be available if the projects were able to go ahead. That project has been banned locally.

It is worth recalling the story about the police academy. It indicates a great deal about the motives of some of these people. One might say it is a parochial issue but it reflects a great deal more than the local situation. The contract for the police academy has been let to a local firm and by now about 40 people should have been working on the project. On 6 August this year it was black- banned by the union, so those 40 jobs are not filled at present. The reason for that is that there was an accident at the Jolimont site, a workman was injured and-there is no doubt about this-there were problems in relation to his workers' compensation. A dispute developed between two worker's compensation insurers as to who was liable, which perhaps indicates the need for reform in that area. I do not condone such disputes. The union conducted a sit-in at one of the insurance offices. After some time some police officers went to the office. They did not forcibly evict the union members; they asked them to leave and they left . The black ban was placed on the police academy site and the union demanded that the police officers give an undertaking that they would never again interfere, as it was called, with union activities. The union saw itself as being above the law in this regard. I do not think many reasonable people would want the police to give such undertakings to the union or to any other section of this community, but the ban continues. One might say it is only 40 jobs, but as far as I am concerned it is 40 jobs that people in the Territory could have.

At present there are bans on various carpet firms in Fyshwick. The demand is being made that sub-contract carpet layers join a union. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Fraser Government's hollow and superficial response to Australia's economic collapse. The Australian Democrats are not prepared to accept a wages pause unless it is accompanied by an overall package which attempts to address the fundamental problems of the economy and at the same time seeks to control prices, dividends, directors' fees and all the other aspects of cost in the economy. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner, pointed to the high levels of unemployment in other countries. He indicated that these had existed for some time and implied that Australia was just starting in this regard and we had to sit back and cop it for some years to come. This is not an attitude that I and my party are prepared to accept. I wish to use most of the time available to outline the solutions as the Australian Democrats see them. Only Churchill had the right words to describe the present Administration. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: No government has ever combined so passionate a lust for power with such incurable impotence in its exercise.

This Government's lust for power has rendered it incapable of thinking about anything else. It has become paralysed by the fear of the political consequences of any of its actions. It is racked by scandal, it is white-anted by corruption and it is corroded by incompetence.

Why has this appalling state of affairs come about? How has it been allowed to happen? Until recently most thoughtful people thought that the problem of a serious recession or depression was a thing of the past-were not governments now practised in the use of the many economic tools available and committed to counter cyclical intervention in the economy? The unfortunate fact is that this Government is so committed to a particular ideology that it has failed to act in a counter cyclical manner. As President Hoover did in the 1930s, this Government has cut spending at a time of reduced business activity. It has attempted to fight inflation first rather than to put people first.

What are the consequences of this? We now have extremely high rates of inflation and extremely high levels of unemployment, and in addition we have a critical balance of payments problem. They are three vital economic indicators, all going through the roof at the same time. Last year we had a $9.1 billion deficit on our current account and this year the figure promises to be even higher. If truly massive amounts of capital had not flowed into Australia, we would have been internationally insolvent. Even a very cursory survey of the present Budget makes it clear that the Government is still attempting to pursue this policy of attracting foreign capital into the country. But the price we pay for this solution to our balance of trade problems is very high indeed. Not only are interest rates kept high to attract money into the country but also we pay the piper in the form of increasing foreign penetration of our economy. We are gradually handing over our destiny to foreign investors and to bankers. Worst of all, we are creating a crippling interest and profit repatriation burden for the future. In relation to this matter, Sir Roderick Carnegie has said:

If you get $2 in 1979 from overseas invested in equities those owners want a dollar a year from 1990 onwards forever. What I'm saying is this: that's a very high price because they see the $2 coming in today but in ten, eleven years' time a dollar going out is an enormous price to pay . . . in the long term I don 't think it's going to create the kind of jobs for young Australians which I want for my kids.

What should the Government do? As we see it, at this late stage only two initiatives are available to it. They are two initiatives that will give the economy a short, sharp shock, which is what it needs if it is to be pulled out of the tailspin it is in, heading towards depression. The Australian Democrats see as the first initiative a significant devaluation of the Australian dollar. We would seek the co-operation of the union movement to ensure that the benefits of the devaluation were not lost through excessive wage demands. Australia is a sufficiently small country that a significant devaluation would not bring about international rebuke, nor would it trigger off a round of similar devaluations.

The second short, sharp shock that this economy needs is the adoption of import restrictions. We advocate adopting this policy as a temporary measure only. We believe that it would have to be selective and reasonable but also very determined. It would have to be based on reciprocity, imposing restrictions where restrictions are imposed on products that Australia exports. For example, the Japanese have consistently forced us to renegotiate contracts and on occasions they have simply refused to take delivery of or to pay for contracted tonnages of coal or iron. Australia is one of the few countries in the world that enjoys a favourable balance of trade with Japan. We would be very foolish if we put this happy state of affairs at risk. But we should demand a quid pro quo with the Japanese.

The Australian Democrats certainly support closer economic relations with New Zealand providing we are not ripped off. We support without reservation the continuation of the friendly and co-operative programs such as we have at the moment with countries of the South Pacific. Indeed, we have advocated generous economic aid to those countries. The difficulties do not arise with Japan, the tiny countries of the South Pacific or New Zealand. Australia's problems with adverse trade balances are with the massive power blocs of Europe and North America and the rapidly industrialising countries of South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore and Venezuela. Right now we have massive imports of steel being dumped in this country from countries such as South Korea and Taiwan. Our steel producer, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, has only 5 per cent protection against these imports. But when Australia attempts to export its steel products to South Korea or Taiwan they are subject first of all to tariff duties as high as 50 per cent. Every importer into Taiwan or South Korea must be licensed, and imports are barred immediately they affect local industries. On the one hand we face these barriers into those countries and on the other hand those countries are allowed to export their steel using the latest American technology and are subject only to a 5 per cent tariff barrier against competition with the local product.

I therefore urge the Government to introduce import restrictions in the form of import quotas as soon as possible to industries in which imports can be replaced by goods produced by local industry and where the local industry is reasonably competitive with imports. This policy would give local industries breathing space to restructure. It would give us time to provide sufficient jobs for full employment. How can this be done? Of course, under the Industries Assistance Commission legislation which was introduced during the years of the Whitlam Government it is necessary to refer any import restrictions or quotas to the IAC or the Temporary Assistance Authority. Such references, of course, take a lot of time. The Government could argue that its hands are tied and that it cannot act quickly. Nevertheless, there is a very simple solution. Next week when the House of Representatives meets, the Government could introduce a very simple amending Bill which would allow it to reassume the authority it had to apply import quotas before the IAC legislation was introduced. It would be a very simple piece of legislation which would, I am sure, receive the support of all parties in the Senate. This would give the Government the power it needs to act quickly at a time when our international solvency is at risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to go back to the situation of the old Tariff Board where it was a political decision about what happened with protection?

—No; Senator Thomas has misunderstood me. I am advocating that the Government must have the authority to apply import quotas quickly. It does not have that authority at the moment, unless it refers the matter to the IAC. I am saying that that legislation should be amended so that the Government has the power to restrict imports as and when our international balance of payments demands that this be done.

SPEECH.PARA: If we did have import restrictions in the form of quotas as a temporary measure -it should not apply for longer than three years-we could give serious thought to restructuring our industries. I believe the Senate is very well aware of my attitude to restructuring. We must have a process of long term indicative planning. We must bring together the unions, industry and the Government to work out what our long term objectives should be. We cannot have everything. We can have more of one thing and less of something else. We must sort our our priorities. Quotas for a three-year period would give us valuable time to work out our priorities and to put before the Australian people a long term plan worked out in association with governments, industry and trade unions so that the people of this country would know what is expected of them and where they are heading.

Planning in some circles is regarded as anathema. It is regarded almost as being un-Australian. Honourable senators must realise that many countries around the world have adopted this planning process with great success. It is a major factor in the success of countries such as Japan, Singapore, France, West Germany and Sweden. These countries have reduced English-speaking countries to their present miserable state.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that the only factor, Senator?

—It is the major factor. They also have an enlightened attitude to industrial relations. We heard Senator Reid bemoaning the fact that we have strikes. Last year the Senate, for the first time in its history, debated a Bill for industrial democracy which, if adopted, would give a new approach and a new direction to the industrial relations climate in this country. To the Senate's credit, the Industrial Democracy Bill 1981 was passed. It has not yet been passed by the House of Representatives. The countries I mentioned have also adopted industrial democracy. This country must have a basic change of direction . It must change direction by 180 degrees. This is the Government's responsibility. We are in a state of crisis. We are looking to the Government for this basic change of direction. If it does not come quickly, the consequences will indeed be tragic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —One may well ask what would be the position of Australia today had not the Federal Government pursued its strong policy towards containing inflation acknowledging two factors; first, our heavy dependence on resource-produced income which is strongly influenced by overseas commodity prices, and, secondly, overseas income from agriculture. The world is indeed facing a recession. Since Australia is a major trading nation it stands to reason that this disturbance is having some impact in this country. One factor of production that unfortunately is slightly out of step at the moment is the labour or wages factor. Since 1980 wage increases have been moving faster than productivity. For example, average weekly ordinary time earnings of full time adult males rose by 18.2 per cent over the 12 months to the September quarter. Wages increased 50 per cent faster than prices increased over that year. That is one of the contributing problems. Another must be traced back to our conciliation and arbitration system. I think there are too many lawyers in the system. There should be some economists, accountants and other people from the business community on the bench. It has become too legalistic and too divorced from the realities of the world to be effective in the Australian climate of 1982. We have recognised that until 1980 productivity gains were slightly in excess of wage movements. For that reason Australia was performing relatively well. Since that time we have seen Australia's international competitiveness being eroded. Unfortunately, jobs have been destroyed and some industries have disappeared forever.

SPEECH.PARA: The sorry reality, therefore, is that in many sectors we are faced now with the situation that one man's pay increase is unfortunately in some cases another man 's job. I think we must have some more positive responses to the Government's suggestion of a wage freeze. I think it was unfortunate that such a negative reaction was adopted initially by so many of the Premiers. I am pleased to say that there was a positive reaction by my State Premier, the Hon. Robin Gray. If one looks at this matter of public importance one must realise that our Government's actions have not been limited to the wage freeze. One has to look to the Budget brought down in August to see some of the positive approaches. There were substantive tax cuts; raised income thresholds; the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Program; home loan incentives were given through the taxation system; pensioner benefits were increased; family allowances were raised; there were extensions of tax concessions to secondary and primary industries; and there was assistance to the disadvantaged.

In addition to the problems created by the international situation there has been a reduction in economic activity due to the major Australian drought. I mentioned last week that over 90 per cent of farms in New South Wales, over 40 per cent of farms in Queensland and 60 per cent in Victoria have been affected. The Bureau of Agricultural Economics estimated as a result of the drought something like $1,500m loss in net value of rural production. But what has been our response? It has been a very significant one and one which has been appreciated by the farming community. We have introduced fodder subsidies to the value of up to $320m. The subsidy is 80c a month for sheep and $8 a head for cattle a month. In addition to the fodder subsidy there is assistance in meeting interest payments-a farmer essentially pays the first 12 per cent and the Government meets the remainder.

I believe that State governments, as well as the Federal Government, have a responsibility. State governments must look very closely at their charging policies. In yesterday's Press we read of the difficulties being faced by the State Rail Authority of New South Wales because of the drought. With the reduction in activity there is a tendency to increase charges and because of cross subsidisation in pricing we can have a situation in which some price increases can be unfairly reflected in charges to some sectors of the travelling public. I think this is one of the difficulties that all public utility organisations will have to face in Australia. There is a case for some deficit financing in this area rather than raising prices which is reflected as an increase in the cost of living. I repeat that I believe there is a case for some deficit funding.

There is also a case for the Government to give some consideration to deferring the possibility of price increases in relation to petrol for a period so that these increases as a result of devaluation do not get reflected in increased costs to the ordinary working man at a time when he cannot afford it. There is a case for what I might call some sort of price surveillance mechanism. I do not necessarily agree with price controls but there does need to be some sort of restraint over the incomes of, for example, professional people, including doctors but if the Government brought in price controls as some people are suggesting we would be deliberately hitting out against the goose that laid the golden egg. One of the problems of business at present is that it is finding difficulty in recovering its increased costs in the form of increased prices. It is a tragedy that so many businesses are losing money at the moment. Therefore there is negative or no investment. We have to try to change that situation in order to overcome the problem.

A further constraint is that the constitutional power of control over prices rests with State governments. There are other difficulties in controlling prices . How does one control, for example, the prices of fresh vegetables that are in short supply at any point of time throughout the calendar year? This is a difficulty with which no statutory mechanism can really cope properly. At the same time I believe that we must not harm Australian industry because price controls would not affect imported products. As we heard this afternoon, one of the problems facing Australia is unfair import competition where allegedly dumped goods are being placed on the Australian market. I think the Australian Government has played a commendable role in trying to free up trade. We have to be careful to ensure that it will not be at the expense of Australian industry.

I think farmers have shown a very commendable attitude in containing a lot of their costs including wage costs. Farmers believe they have been unfairly affected because all wage increases are ultimately reflected in a farmer's costs whereas their prices are largely determined by international competitive situations. Unfortunately, the mining industry has not shown quite the same commendable restraint. At the height of its economic activity it was the pacesetter in the wages area and it drew hundreds or maybe thousands of people from the public sector, the manufacturing sector, from farms and the like. Now the industry is setting up a cry to free up the system. It is making calls for free trade at a time when prices are low. We acknowledge the plight of the industry, but we must not forget that it was one of the bogy-men of the situation which artificially lifted the wages to secure labour at a time it suited it.

One of the tragedies is that the manufacturing industry always gets singled out as being inefficient and demands protection, but there are a whole host of other industries throughout Australia that have an effective protective mechanism built in. It is not the manufacturing industries that have been the pacesetters in wage increases. The pacesetters have come from other areas such as airline pilots and the transport sector including sea transit. We feel this particularly in Tasmania as we are so heavily dependent on sea transport. It is a problem of our State that Bass Strait is one of the highest cost waterways in the world. Until we can overcome this situation we will have problems in Tasmania. We have to provide encouragement to enterprises to stay in business and to invest, because they are unable to pass on many of their cost increases; their profits are squeezed and the inevitable result is that staff are retrenched. There is a case for the Australian Government to look at providing preference to buying Australian goods at this time. The States, I believe, have a role. For example, I think there is a case for limiting some of the scope of business liabilities in workers' compensation law. Accidents that happen in the home, when a person is preparing to go to work, in some cases are deemed to be subject to workers' compensation liability. I think there needs to be a limit to the monetary amounts that are sometimes paid.

Unions too have a responsibility to provide a greater opportunity to enable young people starting off in their working lives to find a job. The starting rates for many juniors are too high, so the opportunity for them to enter the work force is disappearing. There needs to be a greater flexibility in working arrangements. Demarcation disputes are all too frequent. I believe a system of industrial unions would tend to harmonise a system much better than the position we have at the moment. Unfortunately our tariff system appears to be too open. It is so honest that it is subject to attack. Other countries use more devious measures to protect not only their jobs but also their industries.

The Acting Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, suggested that something like $700m could be saved as a result of a wages pause in the public sector. I believe we too, as parliamentarians, have a responsibility. Maybe we should look at some of our conditions, including our generous superannuation, which is subject to minimum tax liability. In a nutshell, we must meet fair competition. We must sell profitably and we must encourage investment. We must overcome all measures which generate confrontation because at this time there exists the ingredients for society to erupt against itself with the haves against the have nots. That could be a real tragedy for Australia. As a nation, we cannot afford it. I regret that my time has expired and I now move:

According to him, the car collected seven inches of water after a rain storm; the electrical system failed repeatedly; the paint peeled; the parking brake pedal came off; the manual transmision repeatedly popped out of second gear and went into neutral; and the car sat in the dealer's shop for transmission repairs for 135 days over a period of 18 months. The story of his losing battle to have the car repaired satisfactorily was one factor that led the Connecticut legislature to pass its lemon law, despite intense opposition, naturally, from the car industry.

The Connecticut law, which has only just come into force, operates for the duration of a new car's warranty or for the first year of ownership, whichever is less. The California law operates only for the first 12,000 miles of the car' s existence. Presumably if it is sitting in the dealer's yard for this extraordinary length of time it would take some years for it to rack up 12,000 miles or even 12,000 kilometres. The law in Connecticut and California defines a car as a lemon if, within that period, one of two situations arises; firstly, if the car has been to the dealer four times to have the same problem fixed, but the dealer has failed to repair the car properly; and, secondly, if the car has been out of service for more than 30 days in all due to one or more defects.

I wish now to draw attention to another aspect of the report; that is, Rum Jungle rehabilitation. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government should give urgent attention to expediting the settlement of compensation claims and rehabilitation of the area.

I do not think I have to describe where Rum Jungle is on the Finniss River in the Northern Territory. It was associated with previous uranium mining. Let me read just a couple of comments from an article which appeared in the Weekend Australian of 17 November, entitled 'Hiding the eyesore of Rum Jungle'. The article states:
According to the second report of the Ranger uranium environmental inquiry (the Fox report), 100 sq km of the surrounding Finniss River floodplain has been affected by contaminants.

Fish and other aquatic creatures have been almost eliminated from the East Finniss River for between 10 km and 30 km downstream: pandanus palms, reeds, water-lilies and other plants have been killed, says the Fox report.

The radiation protection officer at Melbourne University, Mr F. P. Robotham, in Uranium: Energy Source of the Future? . . . wrote: 'According to an Australian Atomic Energy Commission report, the Rum Jungle project discharged some 2,300 tonnes of manganese, 1,300 tonnes of copper, 200 tonnes of zinc and at least 380 g of radium into the environment.' (Similar figures are quoted by the Fox report .)

Obviously this is a Federal responsibility. The Federal Government has decided that it will allocate $16.2m to the Northern Territory Government for a clean-up of the Rum Jungle area on the Finniss River. I have raised this matter in the chamber on a couple of occasions. I am still not satisfied that the work which will be done by the Northern Territory Government will adequately satisfy the obligations of the Federal Government in this matter.

I want to raise some questions. I do not like to do this in this sort of debate , but I must ask whether the Federal Government's responsibilities to the land owners in that area has been and will be satisfied by the Northern Territory Government work. What attempt has been made to compensate the people who have properties in the area? The Minister may recall that earlier this year I raised the situation of one man who had to get a permit to go on to his property in the 1950s and who, for 22 years, has been trying to move on to the property to live on it. At present he still has been given neither an alternative site nor any compensation for his block. He has made a clear offer in the way that a simple Northern Territory man would do. He has said: 'The block is this big; give me a block somewhere else on which I can retire'. The man is now in his 80s and he is still waiting to retire to his property. It is not enough for the Government to hand the responsibility to the Northern Territory Government and wash its hands of the matter. The Federal Government must make sure that any plan the Northern Territory puts forward not only is an effective plan to rehabilitate the area but also meets the Federal Government's obligations towards those people who own property in that area.
I would like to finish the few comments I want to make by quoting the final paragraph of the article to which I have referred. The article states:

Politicians and mining magnates must cringe at the words of the then Minister for National Development, Senator W. H. Spooner, announcing on May 21, 1962, that operations at Rum Jungle would continue despite lack of contracts: 'The plan of development for Rum Jungle--
Said Senator Spooner-
. . . has provided a useful model for other enterprises in northern Australia'.

I would hope that that is not the case. I would hope that the Minister will make sure that the people who want to move on to their properties in the Finniss River area either will be compensated or given alternative sites to allow them to settle. I would hope that the Minister will make sure that all of the Federal Government responsibilities are met by the plan which has been put forward by the Northern Territory Government and that the plan is not simply something which will patch over or band-aid the terrible disaster that is now the Finniss River area.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, as Chairman of Senate Estimates Committee F and on behalf of the Committee I would like to thank the staff who helped us and also the many officers who appeared before us. They were most helpful. Also, estimates are now being presented in a much better way than used to be the case. The format in which they are being presented reduces the amount of time that a Senate Estimates committee has to spend examining figures that are given to it. We thank the departments for the gradual improvement in presentation. I would like to comment on the need for Estimates committees to be able to meet more often than is now the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the meetings of Estimates Committee E a couple of matters have been brought to my attention relating to aviation which I would now like to take up. One relates to the possible closure of one of the runways at Cambridge Airport which is a small airport alongside Hobart Airport. I know that there is a desire by the Government to get as much local ownership as possible and to cut down expense at smaller airports. The Cambridge Airport at Hobart is an established airport. All of the runways have been established. The runways, including the one that I believe is to be closed from the beginning of next month, do not require much maintenance. The runway which I believe is to close is runway 27/09 -the east-west runway. If the runway is closed there will be a need to use a gravel runway-runway 24/06-which will cause more damage to propellers and so on.

There are several reasons why it is not a good idea to close runway 27/09. I think the decision or thought even to close the runway is quite crazy. The serviceability of 24/06 would be doubtful if there were prolonged rain in the Hobart area. The advice that I have is that in such circumstances the runway would become unserviceable. Also, runway 24/06 would conflict much more with runway 30/12 at the main airport at Hobart which runs almost north-south.

The runway that the Department of Aviation is thinking of closing is into the wind more that the runway that would remain open. There are very unstable and gusty winds in Hobart. I believe there is a need to keep this runway open. The amount of money saved by closing this runway is minimal. As I have already said, the runway is built. It is not a matter of having to put in a runway. The Department may desire, in the long term, to confine all flying operations to the Hobart Airport. That would be crazy. It would result in a considerable amount of money having to be spent on an alternative runway at Hobart Airport when there is already a good little airport that does not interfere very much with operations at the main airport.

Whenever the Department of Aviation wants to justify its action it seems to say : 'A safety factor is involved'. I believe it has said that this particular runway is a little too close to one of the hangars. I do not think that any fatalities have been recorded at Cambridge although several crashes have occurred. Pilots have landed aircraft with their wheels up. I think that back in the days of the Tiger Moth one plane crashed. I think the most recent crash involved a Victor that stalled on take-off. It certainly was not using the runway about which I am talking. The crash was caused by pilot error. It was not caused because of the location of that particular hangar. I can remember when Convairs used to take off at the strip that the Department of Aviation is now talking about closing. That aircraft did not seem to have any trouble when using that particular strip.

The Department of Aviation quite often brings up the matter of safety. During the hearings of Estimates Committee E I commented about the cost of training check pilots. The safety aspects, of course, was brought up. I am not happy about the amount of money that is spent on training check pilots who fly for only a few hours a year. For just a few hours they sit behind some of the pilots who have flown aircraft hundreds of hours a year and they are supposed to be able to check that their performance is satisfactory. The Department's reason for this is that safety is involved. Of course, that is supposed to cover a multitude of things. Millions of dollars are being spent on the training of check pilots. I have said before and I say again: I believe a lot of that money is not necessarily spent in the best way to benefit the airlines. People are sent all over the world to undertake training. Some of the training is undertaken in Australia but quite a lot of it is done in America. Once pilots in the Department have a certain licence capability then they command a certain salary. This is something which I will take up again at the next Estimates committee hearings. I think it is time we saw a correlation between the salaries of pilots and the training they have undertaken. I would like to know where this money is going.

The Cambridge runway is not unsafe because of the location of the hangar. If runway 27/09 is left open, as it should be, then there are certain advantages. It would not interfere as I said earlier with main runway 30/12. I have always felt that if the Department wanted to save money it could have less control of light aircraft in the Hobart area. There was a time when there were established lanes through which the pilots were able to fly. In Melbourne they have established these lanes. Some pilots tend to stray a little from where they should be. Such lanes could be easily established in Hobart, particularly for aircraft operating to the west of the Hobart main airport. There is no need for the Department to have radio control over those pilots. Commercial aircraft only rarely fly over the River Derwent. They usually do so on a pleasant day. It is a pleasant flight. Those people who have flown over the River Derwent and who have seen Hobart on a good day are very lucky. It was a very good day in Hobart when I went home last Friday. The Department of Aviation does not need to have as much control over all operations to the west of the airport.

The same applies to the east of the airport. There could be two or three lanes which are easy to remain in and which have good navigation points. I am sure the Government could save more money by doing that than by closing the strip which is completely serviceable. If the weeds are kept down by some means then I am sure that the bitumen strip would last for a considerable time. I believe that the Minister for Aviation (Mr Fife) is visiting Hobart on 29 November. I intend to see him then about this matter. I would like to ask the Government why it wants to close that strip at Hobart. How much money does it think it will save by closing that airstrip?

I wish to raise another matter which has come up since the hearings of Estimates Committee F. I refer to the examinations that are held in this country for commercial pilots' licences. Perhaps this applies to other examinations but only those involving commercial pilots have been brought to my attention. I believe that last year only two lots of examinations were held. The reason given to me was that the Department of Aviation was transferring to Canberra. If the Department is stupid enough to want to come to Canberra I do not see why pilots who want to get a licence to help them gain their livelihood should have to wait around at the Department's whim. I believe that these examinations are held only three times a year. Once these examinations are held it then takes six weeks to get them marked.

I have not done a test for a commercial pilot's licence. I believe that the questions are multiple choice questions and that the person doing the examination just crosses out certain words or ticks a particular box. Those types of examination papers which contain a number of boxes that are ticked or marked can be corrected very easily by putting a cover sheet over them. One can see very quickly whether the answer is right or wrong. I do not see why it takes the Department six weeks to get around to marking those examination papers. If the Department states that the delay is due to the number of examinations then why cannot it stagger the examinations in certain areas of the country? I believe that the Department conducts examinations in Sydney and Melbourne on the same day. I do not see why that it necessary. If all the examinations are held at the same time then maybe the Department has to mark them all at once. It is crazy for the Department to take six weeks to mark the examination papers. I do not know why the Department cannot hold these examinations more frequently. I have asked a question in this place in relation to this matter. I thought that I would have had a reply by now. If it is possible I would like the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) to explain why it takes so long for the Department of Aviation to get around to marking those examination papers.
