SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the points made by Senator Townley, particularly the point concerning the evidence that for years has been given to the Estimates committees, first of all when looking at the then Department of Transport, now the Department of Aviation, with respect to the training of examiners of airmen for the more exotic types of regular public transport aircraft. I refer to the business of flying examiners to America, paying their expenses there, putting them through a very short period flying each year-10 to 12 hours-and some simulator flying time and then bringing them back to sit in judgment on professional pilots who are flying around 70 to 80 hours a month for nine or 10 months a year. It is quite simply a waste of time. The Department has never been able to justify the situation intellectually, professionally or in any other way to the Estimates committee in the years that I have been on it. One can only assume in a most charitable way that it is hallowed by tradition, that tradition dies hard and that no one is prepared to change.

SPEECH.PARA: The position is analogous to someone doing medicine, never practising, being given about 10 or 15 hours a year in a hospital operating theatre and then sitting in judgment on specialist surgeons. The point is that it is not simply a matter of technical knowledge. It is a matter of professional judgment having to be exercised; and judgment comes through experience and repetition. We have fought this fight and intend to keep fighting it before the Estimates committees until we get a satisfactory justification as to why these very large expenses should be a charge against the Australian taxpayer. Since the Estimates committee completed its hearings one incident has come up that is quite relevant . That concerned the operations of a Qantas Airways Ltd aircraft.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was talking about the practice of the Department of Aviation in maintaining as examiners of airmen people with current experience on the types of aircraft used in this country. I was pointing out the great economic penalty and the dubious benefit of these practices with respect to the larger transport aircraft. Since the Estimates Committee dealt with this matter another couple of points of relevance in relation to surveyors and examiners of airmen have arisen which are worth commenting on. First of all, there is the matter of Seattle Airport. Honourable senators will remember that Qantas wished to originate a flight with paying passengers in the course of the delivery of a new aircraft out of one of the airports at Seattle. Before Qantas could operate that service the Department of Transport demanded that surveyors be flown in to have a look at this airfield in Seattle to see whether it was safe for Qantas to operate out of, despite the objections of Qantas management at the time that this was an unnecessary impost on the Australian taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: This really was a ludicrous situation for three very good reasons. First of all , this airport has something like 100 wide-bodied movements either a day or a week out of it. Those aircraft are the Tristar, the DC10, the Airbus or the 747 which have requirements comparable to those of the 747 that Qantas was proposing to work out of this airport. In no sense was it a bush strip. It certainly met the American standards. Secondly, Qantas's own judgment was that the airfield there was quite safe to operate out of. I think that the Department had an obligation to consider Qantas's position most carefully in this matter because Qantas has an exemplary record in aircraft operations and the practices it follows. Of course, Qantas is one of the most experienced wide-bodied operators in the world. It is an airline whose fleet is entirely composed of wide-bodied aircraft, operating exclusively Boeing 747 aircraft. If Qantas's flight operations were prepared to clear the airport as suitable for operations I would have thought that that was an authoritative enough statement in itself.

Finally, the particular airfield in Seattle is approved by the Department of Aviation in Australia as an alternate for Qantas's operations, presumably into Vancouver. That means that Qantas can fly into this airport, refuel or disembark passengers there and fly out without any let or hindrance on its operations. It is quite legal for it to do that. The ludicrous situation arose that Qantas could not originate a flight there to take out paying passengers. The conclusion is rather difficult to avoid-that it was either an over-zealous use of authority or someone simply wanted a trip to North America to have a look at this field. There was a similar situation at about the same time with respect to Nicosia and picking up people going to the Commonwealth Games which were recently held in Brisbane. Again, Nicosia has been an approved alternative airfield for Qantas for many years. We will go into this matter with the Department in greater detail before an Estimates committee, probably during consideration of the Supplementary Estimates in March.

There is a need for the Department constantly to review its policies and not to be ossified. One of these matters came up in Canberra last Friday when British Aerospace Australia Ltd demonstrated the new BA146 feeder airliner. I am not pushing the case for the 146; I just use it as an illustration of the need for the Department to review its policies. The Department has a policy that no jet aircraft operating on a regular public transport service can operate outside controlled airspace. That means that you cannot fly a jet passenger aircraft into an uncontrolled airfield. Many of our small country airfields are uncontrolled; they do not have a tower manned on a continuous basis. Yet, airlines are allowed to fly propeller-driven aircraft or turbo-prop aircraft into uncontrolled airfields. That was a fair enough decision years ago when the first generation of jet aircraft had problems, particularly in the low speed handling regime. They could not operate with conflicting traffic.

The basic point now is that the modern generation of jet aircraft being built for this role have good pilot visibility, very good handling characteristics in the low speed regime in their approach and circuit speeds, and some of them have low tyre pressures suitable for operating off gravel. It is quite a different case from the first generation of aircraft. The parameter to be set is not whether the aircraft is a jet aircraft or a turbo-prop aircraft; the number of movements into a field should determine whether it and the air space around it should be controlled. If only a small number of aircraft arrive and depart in a day there is no need to go to the expense of putting in a tower and controlling air space around that field, because operations can be made on a see and be seen basis quite safely.

We will see more aircraft like the BA146 coming into Australia in the decades to come, and I hope that the Department reviews its policies because the ability to operate these types of aircraft into the regional centres of Australia will be of great economic benefit to us. People who live in outback Queensland and outback New South Wales have very big distances to travel. There is a drift away from those country areas into the cities and if we are to keep people living there we have to provide them with the most efficient and cost effective form of transport, which increasingly will be jet aircraft.

The other matter which I raise has caused great concern to many people who use charter aircraft. At the Estimates Committee hearing on 20 September 1982, I asked:

Does the Department take any measures to advise potential hirers of charter aircraft that they will not be covered by insurance? Has any thought been given to that matter? Innocent people who charter an aircraft might be under the belief that they are covered by insurance and actually they are not if the aircraft or those concerned are not licensed to carry . . . passengers.
The answer I received stated:

The Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act 1959 sets limits on liability for all operators holding an airline or charter licence issued under the Air Navigation Regulations. In this regard all operations carried out under a charter licence come within the ambit of the Act. The Act does not provide insurance cover nor does it require operators to take such cover. However, the Act imposes a liability on the carrier, and injured parties are not required to first prove fault or negligence on the part of the carrier, as would be required under common law action.

The ad hoc nature of the charter industry does not give the Department access to individual hirers. However, the Department actively encourages all charter operators to take out insurance during the licensing process, although there are no requirements under Commonwealth or State legislation for aircraft operators to carry liability insurance.
A compulsory insurance system is one of the matters currently under consideration in the Joint Commonwealth/State Government context.

In respect of that answer, I ask: What progress has now been made in the consideration that has been given to a compulsory insurance system which will operate in a joint Commonwealth-State government context? TALK.START.PARA: -I wish to pursue quite a few questions under the heading of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The questions do not actually come under the responsibility of that Department. They concern the Aboriginal Development Commission. I did ask a whole series of questions during the Estimates Committee hearings. As it is just two calendar months today since I asked those questions I would have expected to have been provided with the answers. Unfortunately, as so often happens when I raise matters concerning the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd, I do not get very much satisfaction either in this chamber or by way of the questions I have asked on Estimates committees over the years. The first question I raised is dealt with on page 744 of Estimates Committee G and the answer was included in the written replies to questions asked during the Estimates hearings. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: May we have a list of the properties which you saw fit to investigate to ensure , to use your term, that the Aborigines were not being ripped off?
Mr Perkins, who is the Chairman of ADC, replied:
We can provide you with that and the breakdown of the investigation costs for each property, as well as the legal costs.
However, when we received the written replies to Estimates Committee G we found his answer was as follows:

It is not possible to provide the Committee with an accurate breakdown on the applications which Commission staff have investigated. Although all purchases which have occurred since the Commission's inception on 1 July 1980 have been investigated. The total number of purchases since 1 July 1980 are 16.

Because of the amount of work which staff would need to undertake in regard to providing information regarding legal and investigation costs associated with each application investigated we are not able to provide the Committee with an accurate breakdown of costs against each property, however, the following investigation and legal costs incurred on land purchases since 1 July 1980 are:

What I was trying to establish was what ADC had expended in legal costs and investigation fees insofar as the agricultural company known as Ralkon is concerned. I was not posing questions on any others. That answer has not been provided to me. I am concerned about it. Later on during the Committee hearing I asked:

Could the Committee have a progressive list of what court cases are still before the court, of those that have been decided and what the judgements are in each of those to this stage, and also the cost to the Commission.
Mr Perkins replied:
We will provide that list.
The reply the Committee has received states:

The reply to this question and questions seven and nine in relation to Ralkon Agricultural is currently being prepared by the Commission's solicitor with the assistance of solicitors representing the commission in Adelaide. Once completed the information required will be made available through the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the Committee.

That information has not yet been made available even though it is two months since I asked the question. I asked further questions the answers to which have not been provided. Question 9 was a question I asked about an instruction which was sent from, I think, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs to the managers of Elders IXL about the amount of money Ralkon could use by way of overdraft. I said:

Mr Viner, when Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, gave an instruction that a stock mortgage was to be made available at a certain level. The company was concerned that it was not getting a fair deal on the sale of its stock. So it wrote to the State Manager of Elders on 9 August. Arising out of that on 13 August, without Elders IXL even asking for a lifting of the upper level of the stock mortgage, suddenly the level was lifted. The company itself did not ask for it. Somebody from some Department-I think it was of Aboriginal Affairs or the ADC-must have instructed Elders IXL to lift that level of borrowing. As I said, the company itself did not ask for it.
In reply Mr Perkins said:

From talking amongst ourselves, I can inform the Committee that we were not involved in that. Certainly according to our information here, we never formally contacted Elders about that. But we will double check that as well just to make sure.
I replied:
To make sure that nobody from the regional office--

I was referring to the regional office of the Aboriginal Development Commission in Adelaide. I was then interrupted but I was going on to say: 'Had instructed Elders IXL to lift the limit of the mortgage available to Ralkon'. In reply Mr Perkins said:

We will double check to make sure that nobody from the regional office has been given any instruction to make any contact of that nature. We will certainly double check to make sure that nothing verbal or written was given.
The reply I received stated:
Please see the reply to question six.
Of course, the reply to question 6 is that the legal officers of the Commission are at present compiling a reply. Question 10 asked:

Would it be possible to get a copy of the instruction that Mr Viner, when the Minister, gave to Elders-I think the company was called Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort then-on the amount that it would be allowed on the stock mortgage?
Senator Baume replied:
Could we undertake to examine the matter and respond to the Committee? I just want to make sure that no issue of confidentiality is involved.
The reply again was:
Please see the reply to question six.

I have had some discussion about these matters with the people at Ralkon. I am disturbed about what I am told by them has been transpiring. This is not the first time I have raised this matter of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. in the Senate. I have raised it on many occasions. I am pleased to see that Senator Baume is now in the chamber. My understanding is that just recently the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs wrote to the chairman of Ralkon saying that because in years gone by his legal company had been acting on behalf of Ralkon, he did not think it fit and proper-I agree with him-that in his capacity as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs he should be involved in any matters concerning Ralkon. He said that Senator Baume would be handling the matter. As we know, Senator Baume was the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for quite some time. He is well conversant with the problems which exist with that company. He was also Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare for a long time. I had a matter referred to that Committee for investigation. As I said earlier, it seems as though every time something is done to try to get some answers to the problems that exist in this matter we run up against a brick wall.

On 27 May 1981 I gave notice of motion in this chamber that a select committee of the Senate be appointed to make inquires and report by 27 August 1981. Of course, if a Committee had been set up it would have reported well over 15 months ago. I will quote the terms of reference of the proposed committee. They are that the committee would be appointed to inquire into and report on:

(a) The viability of the Ralkon Agricultural Company of Loveday Bay Road, Narrung, in the State of South Australia and the competency of the Company to successfully farm (in the interests of the Aboriginal residents of Point McLeay) the three properties it now occupies;
(b) the relationship between the Company, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council from the time of formation of the company in 1975 until 30 June 1980.

Of course, if the select committee is ever set up under the jurisdiction of this Government, that date could be altered to 30 June 1983 which would be three years after the date I designated. The terms of reference also include:
(c) the relationship between the Company, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council and the ADC since July 1980.
(2) The provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings be contained in a subsequent resolution.

Of course, I gave that notice of motion with the concurrence of the official Opposition. This matter was discussed in our Party room and it was decided that a select committee should be set up. However, the committee never was set up because the Government would not agree. I moved to suspend Standing Orders so that this matter could be brought on for debate. However, I was not successful. I hoped that the Australian Democrats would support us but for reasons best known to them they would not do so. As a result, an inquiry has never been held.

Since then, of course, there has been a whole host of cases in the courts. Whilst it has been said to me that it would have cost a lot of money to run the Senate select committee I feel that it has cost a darn sight more money in legal expenses in the meantime, money wasted which could well be spent on the welfare of Aborigines. The Aboriginal Development Commission is wasting Department of Aboriginal Affairs money trying to bring down Ralkon by conducting court cases. I am happy to say that every case the Commission has brought before the court has been thrown out. Ralkon has won and costs have been awarded against the ADC. Only last week another appeal brought before the Federal Court by the ADC was thrown out by three judges without witnesses from Ralkon being called.

Therefore, I say that this is a sorry saga. It is time this matter was put to rest. I hope we do not have to wait until after the next Federal election when we will get a Labor Government for this to happen. Senator Thomas indicates to me that I should wind up my speech. However, this issue is of great concern to the Aboriginal people who live on Ralkon land and at Point MacLeay. I am very saddened to say that this Government is not concerned about their welfare. All it seems to be concerned about is protecting people in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs who were involved in this matter in years gone by. It may even be too late to call some people before an inquiry because a lot of those officers who were involved may now be retired from the Department. However, I am happy to say that if we get a change of Government the decision of my party is that a public inquiry will be held. The sooner we can get a change of government and have this public inquiry the better.

I get back to what I started on. Why cannot the answers be provided? Why have not the legal advisers to the ADC been able to come up with the answers? Why are they hiding behind a cover? I suggest they are doing so because Ralkon's lawyers have been told that they need to be paid before any further cases proceed on behalf of the ADC. They will not go on forever and a day without being paid for the legal expenses that they incur in taking cases to court on behalf of the ADC . As I have said, two calendar months have now gone by since I last asked these questions at the Estimates committee meeting. I have not been provided with an answer. It seems that something smells about the whole thing. Why can we not get this matter over and done with? If there are culprits on either side let them be dealt with, but for goodness sake let us solve the matter. Let the Ralkon Agricultural Co. and the people who live at Point MacLeay farm the beautiful piece of land to the benefit of the Aboriginal people who live there. Why should we be wasting an enormous amount of money which is provided by the taxpayers to the ADC in a continuous round of court litigation for the purpose of trying to prove a point. I say to Senator Baume: It is high time that something was done about this. I know that Senator Baume and his Government will not agree to the establishment of a select committee. Goodness knows, there have been select committees on other matters. Although they have been important, in my view and in the view of many people, nothing is as important as taxpayers' money going down the gurgler, week after week, in useless court cases-actions which are trying to downgrade those fine Aboriginals who farm that property. It is high time something was done. I will await Senator Baume's answer before I have something more to say on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think honourable senators are aware that there has been dissension for some years between the Point McLeay Community Council Inc. and the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd. That company was set up by the Point McLeay Council to operate its farming interests. The present dispute is essentially one regarding which body should have control over the farming enterprise. That is what it is all about. There is an asset and the question is: Who shall control the use of that asset? More particularly, it involves the Aboriginal Development Commission owned portion of the farming enterprise. As Senator McLaren has told us, that part is known as Bartlett's Farm. That is what the dispute is about-who shall control that piece of property. The dispute over control has actually resulted in a number of court actions. My advice in October was that none of those actions has been decided. Senator McLaren may have some more recent information but, in any event, that would not alter the thrust of what I am saying. That is what the dispute is about and that is what the court cases are about. I have been able to bring some extra information into the chamber which may assist Senator McLaren. I can give it without a lot of shouting and yelling. This is a long-standing matter. It is not helped by all the rodomontade--
—How long has it gone on? Year after year. You run away from your responsibilities, that is what you do.

—I wonder whether the honourable senator wants the information or not. In relation to question No. 6 I have been advised by the Aboriginal Development Commission that all the central office files in respect of the Ralkon matter were in Adelaide with the solicitors acting on the Commission's behalf. It took some time to get to the files and to get some of the information required. Question No. 6 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Could the Committee have a progressive list of what court cases are still before the court . . . those that have been decided and what the judgments are in each of those to this stage, and also the cost to the Commission.

As at 17 September-I am not certain but I think that is the date on which the questions were asked-the three matters that related to Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd to which the Aboriginal Development Commission is a party and which were before the courts were as follows: The first matter is action No. 3205 of 1981 in the Supreme Court of South Australia. It involves the Point McLeay Community Council Inc. and the Aboriginal Development Commission versus Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd. At the time of this brief, no judgment had been handed down in this case. It was not possible for the Aboriginal Development Commission to give me any indication of what costs it might incur as that is principally dependent upon the final judicial determination of the matters at issue.

The second matter includes actions Nos G50 of 1981 and G62 of 1981 in the Federal Court of Australia-Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd versus the Aboriginal Development Commission. As at 17 September 1982 these matters were the subject of an appeal by the Aboriginal Development Commission to the Full Federal Court against a decision of Mr Justice Keely on 5 August 1982. I will not go through the grounds of the appeal but the decision was subject to an appeal at that stage. I understand that that appeal has subsequently been decided in favour of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd. I think that might be the case to which Senator McLaren was referring. It is not now a matter before the courts as such although proceedings under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act will no doubt flow as a result of the appeal decision. One cannot say that all of the court actions are complete in relation to that matter. It is not possible at this stage to indicate the final legal costs to the Commission in that matter .

The third matter before the courts is action No. 3054 of 1981 in the Supreme Court of South Australia-the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd versus the Aboriginal Development Commission, Charles Perkins and Wayne Prior. At the time of my advice no judgment had been handed down on this matter. The action is one of alleged defamation. It is presently at the stage of discovery proceedings. It is not possible to indicate what the final legal costs of the Commission will be for that matter. In respect of the above actions I can advise the Committee that a total amount of $19,434.21 has been advanced by the Aboriginal Development Commission to its solicitors. In addition, a further account for disbursement of the amount of $458.78 is outstanding and will be paid shortly. I trust that will assist the honourable senator in relation to question 6. I understand that the important part of question 9 was whether anyone from the ADC had any consultation at all with Elders IXL about the stock mortgage and whether any officers had given any instructions to Elders IXL. The answer I have is that on or about 13 August 1982 the manager of the Adelaide area office of the Aboriginal Development Commission phoned Elders IXL seeking information as to the current level of the stock mortgage loan. No instructions had been given to Elders IXL by officers of the Commission and the Commission had no knowledge of a subsequent lift in the level of borrowing prior to 17 September 1982. Question 10 asked by Senator McLaren was:

Would it be possible to get a copy of the instructions that Mr Viner, when the Minister, gave to Elders-I think the company was called Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort then-on the amount that it would be allowed on the stock mortgage?

The answer provided is that the Aboriginal Development Commission has been unable to locate in any of its files a copy of any instruction given by Mr Viner to Elders concerning the stock mortgage loan ceiling. However, there are on file certain papers which indicate that a ceiling of $30,000 had been set, at least based on some verbal-I take it that means oral-agreement. Certain copies of correspondence allude to an 'existing agreement' but Commission files do not reveal any formal written instruction. That information is provided by the Aboriginal Development Commission in an attempt to provide the outstanding answers to the honourable senator's requests.

Before I sit down I will make only one further comment in relation to a matter raised peripherally by Senator McLaren. It may be a good moment to bring before the Committee the fact that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) will no longer be accepting ministerial responsibility in relation to matters affecting the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd and its affairs. It may be worthwhile making this known to the Parliament. Mr Wilson, before he became a member of parliament, was a partner in the firm of Genders Wilson and Partners. At the time he became a Minister that company did not have any brief which would have involved it in any matters concerning the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Subsequently it did become involved. At no stage was Mr Wilson, now the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, ever involved in the matter. He has no conflict of interest. But because it might appear to some that there could be a conflict of interest or because it might appear improper that the company in which he was formerly a partner has now got the brief, it has been decided that it is most appropriate if Mr Wilson, now the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, takes no part in ministerial decisions involving the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Because some may see a conflict of interest in the situation, the Minister brought the matter quite properly to the attention of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). It has now been decided that, although the Minister will be kept informed on the matter, any ministerial decisions in relation to the dispute in respect of either the company or the Commission will be taken by me as the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It is proper that those details be made known.

I say again, without any apologies to Senator Peter Baume, that I am very sorry that Senator Chaney did not carry on with that endeavour to help those people down there. They are genuine people. They try to help themselves. What has been going on there for years is one of the reasons why Aboriginals are ridiculed by the white people of this nation. The Government is not prepared to let them carry out ventures like this, and particularly Ralkon. The Government has given title to other Aboriginal enterprises and registered companies which are listed in this reply. For some reason or other, the Government will not give it to Ralkon. There have been many meetings of the people down there.

Senator Baume raises the matter of a dispute between the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council and Ralkon. He well knows who is behind all those disputes. I do not have to repeat their names in this chamber. That is one of the reasons why I gave notice of a motion in May last year to set up a Senate select committee to inquire all aspects of this matter. I thought that the terms of reference I proposed were all embracing so that every person who had some interest-whether it be the ADC, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council, the Ralkon directors or any other person down there- would have the opportunity to come forward to make a public submission. I did not want to be on the committee because it could be said that I would be biased. I wanted to see a Senate select committee set up to examine the evidence put before it and then come up with a finding. I have said on many occasions that the people there and I would be prepared to accept whatever recommendations were made by that Senate select committee. But it appears that the Government, in its wisdom, is not prepared to let that inquiry take place. What it wants-this is not only my view but also the view of many other people-is to let the thing drag on and on until many of the people who could be well criticised for creating this problem are gone from the Aboriginal Affairs Department and it is not possible to call them before a committee of inquiry. I say to Senator Baume that if I am still a member of the Senate during the time of the next Parliament I will be pushing for that Senate select committee to be set up and undertake a full inquiry into the problems that exist.

I have said also for the public record that if I am proved wrong in what I have said I will be quite prepared to apologise if I have offended or humilated any person in any way. I am very concerned about this problem. Constituents bring many problems to me but this is the only one about which I find myself waking up in the middle of the night wondering what I can do to help the people concerned and wondering why we have a government in Canberra that has no concern at all for the welfare of these people, who have proved themselves to be good farmers. They can be a success. It might well be that the Government does not want them to be a success and have these projects, which it has delayed for so long, thrown back in its face. It is not only Senator Baume who has been the Minister responsible for this problem. Before him we had Senator Chaney. As I have said, I have given full credit to Senator Chaney for what he tried to do. I give no credit at all to Mr Viner for his actions when he was Minister. I even made a trip to Perth to plead with him to visit the place, to talk to the people and listen to their problems. Of course he could not even go and see them. That is the way that these people have been fobbed off, year after year.

It is a long time since I first raised this matter in the Parliament. I think I first raised the problems of these people long before Senator Baume came into this place. We then had only one farm there, know as Block K, which was under the jurisdiction of the South Australian Aboriginal Trust. That was when I was first asked to go there. It must be all of nine or 10 years since I first became involved and tried to do something under the previous Liberal Government, before Labor came to power, to get these people assistance, to get superphosphate to put on the land so they could run their sheep. They had no cattle, although they do now and the farm is a credit to them.

The other thing about which I am concerned-no answer has been given to my questions-is why the ADC still insists that paid agricultural consultants be sent to the farm. Only a couple of weeks ago they drove through the farm and cut the locks on the gates to get access. They never went to the director or the manager of the company; they just drove in and, with a bolt cutter, cut the locks to the paddocks. The chairman of directors had to follow them and ask what they were doing. So a lot of things are being covered up. I am very concerned about these matters and I make no apology for getting emotional, because human beings are concerned. They are human beings who are downtrodden. In many cases they are Aborigines. In this instance we have a group of Aborigines who have the ability and the desire to prove themselves as worthwhile citizens as other farmers so that they can farm a property which was bought for them under a Labor Government. Every impediment has been put in their way to prevent them from showing that they can be successful farmers.

I could talk my head off about this but I know that Senator Baume will take no notice of me. All he says, as he said a while ago, is that there is no need for me to shout and rant and rage and get emotional. As I said, I make no apologies for that. I believe that the people I am speaking for and the people who have made representation on their behalf are genuine people and if the day does not soon come when they are able to prove their worth all will be lost. They will lose hope and the place will go to the pack. Then the Government will come forward and say: 'Look, we told you so; we knew it would be a failure'. At this time I do not think it is a failure. I plead with Senator Baume tonight to do something about it, to prevent Charles Perkins, the Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, from continuing these court actions and continuing this persecution of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. Goodness knows, it is taxpayers' money that this man is using and it is time that he was removed from the position that he holds. I am sure even the Government is of that opinion now. It is time that someone else took over the job as Chairman of the ADC. The Government, if it likes, can put him back as the Deputy Secretary of Aboriginal Affairs and let someone who has some heart and some feeling for these people at Ralkon take over this job and help prove themselves as a worthwhile Aboriginal company in this community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer particularly to Ralkon Agricultural Company, whose situation has been adequately covered by my colleague, Senator McLaren. I want to endorse a number of things he has said and point out a couple of other facts that ought to be taken into consideration. It is true that Block K goes quite a long way back in the history of the South Australian Aboriginal Trust but in more recent years, particularly the last six or seven, the acreage has been extended. It is the type of property which is well worth developing and with which the Aboriginals themselves have done very well indeed. The cost of the court cases in relation to this matter are quite alarming and I have no doubt that it will be much higher when all the figures have been added up. What amazes me is that, although a question was asked about this in September, it is only now, on 17 November, that any figures can be produced at all. I challenge the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) in regard to the figure quoted and suggest that it is nowhere near what the total cost will prove to be. That money, as Senator McLaren has pointed out, could have been well used in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: I became concerned about the Ralkon matter in 1976. As far as I could ascertain at the time, the problem had been caused by an officer or officers of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. There was present a personality cult, and a determination by white people to even old scores and let the blacks cop what was left. That is the way the system operated. When the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Viner, was asked to intervene by both myself and by Senator McLaren, he was reluctant to do so and in fact helped further to inflame the argument that was going on. Again the pawns in the game were the local Aboriginal people. Senator Chaney tried to help while he was Minister, but overall I suggest that he condoned some of the things that were going on without trying to make any attempt to rectify the situation, so the problem went on and on.

Senator Peter Baume then became involved in the case. He followed the Viner line. He inflamed the argument and helped to create an even worse crises in the Aboriginal community. He did that quite deliberately, probably at the behest of other white people or of someone inside the Department. The Aboriginal Development Commission, at the end of the last financial year, was overprogrammed by some $7m. I could be quite critical of a number of aspects of the work of the Commission. I am not blaming the Board members. I am blaming people associated with the Department of Aboriginal Affairs who have used the method of washing their hands of responsibility, particularly in relation to the spending of cash.

In my area of Mackay a very successful fishing enterprise has been ruined because of this attitude and even the present Minister for Aboriginal Affairs ( Mr Wilson) is not game to intervene. A boat was destroyed and insurance paid. The person who owned the boat was told that the loan money would be set aside and when he found a suitable boat it would be made available. It is no longer available. Another successful business enterprise has been sent to the bottom of the ocean, in the same way as Ralkon will go to the bottom of the harbour unless the Department has enough intestinal fortitude to stand up and do something about the whole situation.

I challenge Senator Peter Baume to go back to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Wilson, who I do not particularly blame. He has held his portfolio for a very short time and does not really know what it is all about. As far as this particular incident is concerned, I heard Senator McLaren say that his legal company was not involved in the matter. That was the story that was told. As I said to Senator Baume across the chamber a while ago, I am telling it now for the fourth time. A letter that came from the Minister today contains two glaring mistakes. In paragraph 3 it is said that the National Aboriginal Council was established by the Commonwealth Government in 1977. That is a complete misstatement of the fact. It might have 36 members under that title. If these inaccuracies are coming out of the Department they ought to be corrected at the departmental level. A Minister who is new at the game and does not really know when things were started can be used by a letter being drafted for him and his being made to look an idiot. It was started before the Labor Government went out of office and continued after that, with certain alterations. I think there were 42 or 43 in the original Council.

Then there is an appeal for members and senators to talk to NAC representatives . In a far northern district the Minister is really helpful-or his advisers are- in saying: 'If you want to see the representative of QED you will find her office address at 159 Flinders Street, Hermit Park'. The street number and name are right, but that suburb is several miles from Flinders Street so a letter posted to that address would not reach her. They say: 'If you want to contact the NAC representative at home you will find her at 6 Surrey Street, Townsville' . Surrey Street is the right address but, without the suburb being named any letter posted to that address would not reach her. There are probably other mistakes. Those were made in my own area and I know the two addresses concerned.

I do not know what is happening to the DAA. It has been reduced to a stage at which it is in bits and pieces, as it was in Peter Howson's day. So many things are tagged on. Nobody cares-the Government least of all. It is hiding money under various cases in an attempt to prove that in real terms it is spending as much or more than it did in the past, and it is not. The Aborigines are suffering. The legal service has been denigrated. It has been reduced to little more than a plaything of the Minister. Minister Baume is aware of the arguments I have had with him over the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders Legal Service and the new so-called committee system. The only people who are suffering are the Aborigines who need urgent legal advice. They can no longer get it. They are going into the courts in country districts now without any legal advice at all. Today I had a phone call from the far northern parts of Western Australia, where somebody is in serious trouble. The Aboriginal legal service did nothing at the start because it does not have the necessary money or personnel; its personnel are scattered all over the place-thin on the ground.

For the Minister to say that this Government has done more than any other government to look after Aborigines is a downright fabrication. Minister Baume was the man who said here one day: 'We guarantee that the new land rights system in Queensland will be adhered to'. Now, of course, the exponents of democracy and justice in the Queensland Government are taking thousands of acres of ground off every one of those reserves and saying: 'This was not in it in the first place'. What is this Government doing? It is sitting back and saying: 'Good on you, Joh. Take it off the blacks. They do not need it anyway.' That is exactly what the Government is doing by agreeing with what is happening. I hope this matter is properly investigated. I also will support the establishment of a select committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that in the Committee of the Whole we should not have to seek answers to questions; we should debate the matters referred to in the Estimates committee hearings. It is disturbing if the information we ask for in those committee hearings is not provided, particularly if it should come from departments. I was disturbed at the number of times during the day that I heard colleagues say: 'I asked for this information and do not have it'.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to a question I asked in the hearings of Estimates Committee G to do with the review of electoral boundaries. When I raised the question in the Committee hearings the departmental officer said that the size of the National Aboriginal Conference was determined by government decision; the Government would make its decision on the size of the NAC on the basis of the amount of business and the nature of the business that the NAC had to consider. The Committee report states:

Therefore, it is somewhat confusing to the Committee as to the real purpose of this review of existing electoral boundaries. It would therefore appear to the Committee that there is a lack of clear guidelines associated with this review and in fact the general comments on this item in the explanatory notes are misleading.

We have no further information, although further information was promised. I now ask the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) the following questions: What are the reasons for the review of the boundaries for the NAC? Why was the decision made that the boundaries needed to be reviewed? Was it that the Aboriginal people themselves asked for this to be done, or was it a Government decision based on other information in front of it? What was the amount of $173, 000 going to be spent on? Will it be used for the commissioning of a consultant, for transport or what? The last question I ask is: Who will carry out this review of the electoral boundaries of the NAC?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was when I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that the need for a review of the electoral boundaries became necessary. It was partly as a result of requests put to us by Aboriginal members of the National Aboriginal Conference at the time. It was in the year leading up to the last NAC election. In one of my first meetings with the NAC a number of the members told me that they thought the boundaries were unsatisfactory. They were unsatisfactory for a variety of reasons. Some of the members representing Queensland electorates wanted, I remember, minor adjustments to their boundaries. I think they are like politicians everywhere-some of them had electoral reasons for wanting these changes. But requests did come from members of the NAC at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: It seemed inappropriate, impossible in fact, to review the boundaries before that NAC election. For one thing, the qualifications needed to become a candidate for the election required people to reside in the electorates for a certain period. If we had undertaken an exercise to review the boundaries and had not had it in place in time we might have disfranchised a lot of people who might have wanted to be candidates. So there were good reasons why it could not be done when the requests were first made.

There were other reasons why the review looked appropriate. There were concerns from some of the people who for broad kinship reasons thought the boundaries were inappropriate. One area that obviously needed another look was the area in central Australia where State and Territory boundaries have created boundaries to some NAC electorates. Other considerations-such as reasons of Aboriginality, which Senator Robertson will appreciate-suggested there might be a case for some of their electorates going across our administrative boundaries. Those decisions are very major ones and obviously required a fair amount of examination as to what the issues were. I remind the honourable senator that there have been a number of reviews in the past which have been used to assist in determining whether there should be a review and how boundaries should be determined. I think Dr Hiatt did a review some years ago. I think Senator Keeffe referred to the first committee that was formed. The Hiatt review at that stage helped determine boundaries.

The Government agreed in April 1981 that an independent review of NAC electorates should be conducted in consultation with the Australian Electoral Office. The difficulty was that we needed somebody who was experienced in electoral matters and Aboriginals who were experienced in Aboriginal matters to work together to carry out this review. The cost of this was to be met from the global funds allocated for Aboriginal advancement programs. As Minister at the time I can say that there was no difficulty with that. We could accommodate that . It had been requested from Aboriginal people and it seemed reasonable. The proposals had come to us from the NAC which had proposed not only that the boundaries be reviewed but also that the membership itself be increased.

I cannot answer from the information I have available to me at the moment some of the detailed questions which Senator Robertson has asked about the allocation of money. I think there is no difficulty in obtaining that information. I can seek to obtain the detailed information from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs , Mr Wilson, and let the honourable senator have it. But I think the Minister will agree that, in light of the representations that have been made about the unsatisfactory nature of the boundaries and in view of the fact that we had to get the NAC election out of the way first, a review should take place as quickly as possible. When that is in place enough time will have elapsed before the next NAC election for candidates to emerge and for people to organise themselves. To the extent that Senator Robertson's questions have not all been answered I will undertake to try to get the information and to get it quickly for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not take up much of the time of the Committee. I thank the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) for that information but I draw attention once again to the fact that the information which he has given to us tonight is at his fingertips. We could have had it at the Estimates committees and certainly the information which he has promised to get for me now could have been provided at the time when the Estimates committees were held and tonight. I would like to ask for some more details on this matter. I am trying to make the point strongly that we ought to have the information in front of us. We would not misuse some of our time here seeking information when we ought to be making comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point I wish to raise tonight is probably in a different vein from the points raised by the previous speakers, but it is in relation to the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation Corporation. The reason I raise this matter is that the Committee is looking at the estimates of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. The report of the Corporation was brought down . When the report came before the Parliament it was one of those days when there was no time for discussion on the matters that were listed. On reading the report I am amazed to find that the Sports Foundation has been in existence for approximately 10 years. When one reads through the report one finds that the Aboriginal Sports Foundation has done a number of reasonable things for Aboriginal sports participants in the States throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: At the moment I wish only to deal with Queensland and then move on to what is being done for the Aboriginal sporting groups. If one looks at the 10 years that the Sports Foundation has been in operation, really a great deal has not been done. If one looks at the Commonwealth Games in Brisbane, one would have to ask the question why more Aboriginals were not participating or representing Australia at the Games. When one looks at Britain and a number of other countries one finds that a number of coloured people represented the various countries throughout the Commonwealth. I think the only Aboriginal sportsman-I stand to be corrected on this point-who represented Australia was in boxing. I did not see any Aboriginals in athletics or the other field sports in which we were participating at the Commonwealth Games. If the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation has been doing the job it has been set up to do-I believe there is enough talent amongst the Aboriginal community within Australia-some of those people should have been brought to a level where they could have been participating in international sport and could have represented Australia at the Commonwealth Games. Perhaps that is not the fault of the people who have been participating in the sports. Perhaps it is because of the facilities which were available to the Aboriginal community generally through the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation.

I believe it is reasonable for the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson) to give some consideration to this matter in the future. If Aboriginals have not reached the level of international sport at this stage some sort of training facilities should be set aside at the Australian Institute of Sport so that the trainers can go to school and be trained. This would mean that there would be a lifting of the standards of Aboriginal sports people participating in sport and this would give support to the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation Corporation . It is worth while considering that trainers should be trained at the Institute of Sport even if the people they are training do not meet the requirements to enable them to attend the Sports Institute. This certainly means that if the trainers were trained the general standard of the sport of Aboriginals throughout Australia would be lifted, particularly those who are being looked after by the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation Corporation. It is worth while quoting a letter that was written to the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume. It states:
I have much pleasure in submitting the 1980-81 Annual Report of the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation Corporation, incorporating the audited accounts for the year ended 30 June 1981.
The report outlines the efforts and activities of the Foundation during the year under review.
The National Aboriginal Sports Foundation Corporation firmly believes in the valuable role sport can play in the social and cultural development of the Aboriginal and Island people of Australia.

Anything that goes towards developing sporting activity within the Aboriginal community should be undertaken. I only make the suggestion that the Minister take this matter on board and give consideration to what has been said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will certainly make Senator Jones's views known to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson). I make only one brief comment. The honourable senator will understand that there is some slight diffidence for us as non-Aboriginals-not counting you, Mr Temporary Chairman-in trying to lay down or be prescriptive about the things that should be done for Aboriginal people. The honourable senator may be interested to know that the National Aboriginal Conference, as the elected body representing Aboriginal people, was asked to address itself to questions such as this, how sporting arrangments should be made and whether the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation Corporation was or should continue to be the appropriate body. I am not sure whether the NAC has reported. It had not reported some months ago. When I do write to the Minister with the honourable senator's request I think he would understand that the matter would be considered alongside the Aboriginal viewpoint which would emerge from the National Aboriginal Conference.
—I thank the Minister for making that distinction. I appreciate it.

—I do not wish to keep the matter going, but I will be writing a letter to the National Aboriginal Sports Foundation Corporation with some humble quotations and I will make the suggestion I made. I will ask that the Foundation Corporation consider that suggestion when it makes its submission to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Wilson).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the Estimates Committee hearings , in response to a question from Senator Ryan, it was agreed that the current allocation of funds for family planning included a factor of only 8 per cent to allow for inflation in the 1982-83 period, despite the fact that the Government' s own estimate of inflation during that period was 10.5 per cent and, as we have seen, it is likely to blow out to considerably more than that. On asking what the effect was likely to be on family planning services, whether there were to be cuts in education programs or publicity or whether the level of services was to be diminished, we were unable to receive any very firm information. We were assured that the decision had been taken by the Government in the Budget context , so it was to the Government that we should look for a response to that question. In view of the fact that there is to be this shortfall in real funding and an increased number of patients to be dealt with-for many no return would be received; the people known as 'unbillables'-I thought it might be of interest to quote from a statement made recently by the National Health and Medical Research Council at its 93rd session in June 1982 concerning adolescent pregnancy. The statement read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Council noted that there had been a decline in childbirth confinements among teenage girls, less marked among the age group under 16 years where the rates declined more slowly. The Council considered that this decline may have been associated, among other things, with increased community acceptance of the need for teenagers to have access to contraceptive advice and with a positive response by teenagers themselves.

The Council recommended that efforts should be made to further promote the availability of the access to family planning information and the provision of advice for sexually active teenagers and that support continue for initiatives of this type.

Furthermore, Council recommended that in order to promote responsible attitudes to sexuality among teenagers, training programs at post-graduate level should be available for teachers, health professionals and other resource personnel involved in health education programs for adolescents and their families.

The Council approved in principle the need for special emphasis on antenatal care for pregnant teenagers. However, it recognised that the limited experience in Australia, the scattered nature of much of the population, the mobility of teenagers and the decline in births among teenagers meant that it may not be feasible or practicable to establish facilities directed solely to unmarried teenagers.

It therefore, recommended that antenatal departments in hospitals undertake reviews of their procedures and approach to pregnant teenagers in order to encourage better use of the existing facilities. Because of the high risk nature of teenage pregnancies, the Council considered that a comprehensive range of social and medical support systems are required.

The really significant part of that statement in relation to family planning is, of course, the emphasis on the need for preventive advice for young teenagers, access to contraceptive advice, and promotion of the availability of that access to sexually active teenagers. There was also emphasis on training programs at the post-graduate level and a comprehensive range of social and medical support systems. I suggest that this, plus maintenance of the current levels and activities, are expected to be achieved on a less than inflation increase of funds of 8 per cent for the current year. It seems bizarre to me that the family planning services of this country-overstretched as they have been during the last few years, being forced to cut back on crucial education programs and on their publicity and unable to keep up with the immense demand on their services at a time of financial and economic stress amongst the poorer people in our community-are being expected to further stretch their funds to keep up the level of their services. Apparently the Government is unprepared even to maintain the services at their current level.

I would be very grateful to have some indication from the Minister about whether the Government has an awareness of this state of affairs and whether it would be prepared, if given evidence of the need for extra funds, to give further consideration to maintaining the funds at least at their real 1981-82 levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a matter with regard to health services research and development grants. Application forms for the health services research and development grants were apparently circulated by ANZSERCH and the Australian Private Hospitals Association in December of 1981 . The accompanying leaflet stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Department of Health invites applications for grants for investigations into health care services from individuals, organisations and government authorities.

The purposes of the grants were to improve through research, amongst other things, the evaluation, planning and delivery of health care in Australia and to provide information which would assist-presumably the Department-in the development of health services policy. The pamphlet went on to state:
The research should have some unique elements and be relevant to the Australian health care system.

The pamphlet listed amongst some fields of research which it said were of particular interest and relevance 'research into rehabilitation services'. At the bottom of the pamphlet was the additional comment that further information could be obtained from the Director of Research Grants Section of the Department of Health. It gave a post office box number in Woden and also a telephone number . In January of 1982-that is, a month after this leaflet was circulated-a constituent of mine applied for a grant to research morbidity and mortality characteristics of Australian veterans. As I have said, that was in January of 1982 in response to an application form which was circulated in December of 1981 . In September of 1982 this constituent received a letter which stated:
Your application for a research grant to conduct this study was considered by the Health Services Research Grants Task Force at its recent meeting.
I have no idea whether that recent meeting which was referred to was the only meeting the task force had held or whether it was dealing with applications over a period. The letter went on to state:

Although your application was received in January this year, there has been a freeze on funds for the Health Services Research and Development Grants Program, which has only recently been lifted. This accounts for the apparent delay in processing your application.
I would have thought nine months was little more than an apparent delay, but I dare say the Department of Health knows best. The letter continued:
In view of this delay the Task Force felt there was no point in considering your application at this stage, in view of the possibility of funding in 1983 by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

Again, the letter does not say whether the doctor concerned had to apply separately to the Department of Veterans' Affairs or whether in its wisdom and mercy the Department of Health was going to pass on the original application to the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The Director, Grants and Evaluation Section , said in the last sentence of his letter that he was writing to the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs to inform him of this decision. But again , it does not give any indication to the doctor concerned whether the information from the Director was going to be sufficient for the grant to be considered.

I think this raises a number of questions. First of all, it raises the question why, if a freeze were applied early in 1982-I presume it was early in 1982 since the freeze was lifted recently and the word 'recently' was used around September 1982-applications were circulated in December of 1981. One would have assumed that the Department of Health would have known in December-presumably it is a normally efficient government department-that there was going to be a freeze early in 1982 and would therefore not have bothered to ask people to go to all the trouble of coming up with an application, giving justification and so on for what are in effect fairly esoteric research requirements. Why did it take so long anyway for the Department to reply to this doctor's application? I say again that I find it odd that the Department of Health refers to the delay as an 'apparent delay' when there was a nine-month period between its receiving and responding to the application. Could the Department give me a little more information about when the freeze was lifted because 'recently' is rather a vague term, for how long it is going to be lifted and why the decision was made in the first place that having lifted the freeze it considered that the grant applied for on the topic of morbidity and mortality characteristics of Australian veterans did not qualify, apparently anyway, for a grant under the health services research and development grants? Furthermore, since the latest information I have is that nothing further has come from this, could the Department say what decision has been made by the Department of Veterans' Affairs with respect to the reference that the Department of Health made to it concerning this grants application?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just respond briefly to Senator Giles to say that we have noted the comments she has made with regard to the level of funding for family planning and I will draw the attention of the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) to her comments. Senator Haines raised a number of questions which will need to be referred to the Department of Health and the Minister for some response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —An education kit for family planning, which was prepared by the Queensland Department of Health with the assistance of the Family Planning Association, was the subject of a question during the hearings of Estimates Committee G which was very adequately answered by the Department of Health. This matter concerned the use of a drug known as Depo- provera about which there has been a fair bit of discussion, some of it not particularly well informed, in the Australian Press over the last few months. I thought I might take the opportunity to refer to some of the material provided by the Department and some other information that I have.

SPEECH.PARA: An immense literature amounting to more than 800 references has now accumulated on the subject of injectable steroid contraceptives in general and depot medroxyprogesterone acetate in particular. The concept of long acting contraceptives has continuing appeal to many groups of women in all walks of life and to their medical attendants. It is estimated that one and a half million women around the world are currently using them. Injectable contraceptives have been used widely in many developing countries and in a smaller number of developed countries. Continuing controversy surrounds several unresolved problems.

There is considerable appeal to injectable contraceptives on a number of grounds. They are highly effective and long acting. They are simple to administer and independent of coitus. There is no suppression of lactation. There is a minimal degree of gastro-intestinal disturbances. They have the added advantage not only in developing countries but also in developed countries of requiring a regular one monthly to six monthly contact with health personnel which may be highly desirable.

There are a number of incompletely resolved issues and some of them are quite worrying. The menstrual side effects of Depo-provera have been the subject of a three day World Health Organisation experts symposium. Injectable contraceptives almost invariably produce major disturbances of the menstrual pattern. Their disadvantages include the fact that, once injected, they cannot be quickly removed from the system. As I said, menstrual disturbances can be very unpleasant. They vary from heavy prolonged bleeding to very infrequent bleeding. Some of the side effects are common to the whole range of oral contraceptives and include weight gain, headaches, bloating and mood changes including unpleasant feelings of dizziness, fatigue and loss of libido. These are all common to the symptoms reported by users of a wide range of oral contraceptives.

More serious effects however-these are the unresolved issues-are variability in duration of action, unpredictable return to fertility and possible foetal effects. There have been reports of congenital abnormalities and virilisation in experimental work with animals-a risk calculated by the Population Council at something like seven in 10,000 births. The blood levels of these drugs also may persist long after the last dose. These are serious questions but they are always addressed by responsible practitioners. There may be an increase in the risk of cytological abnormalities of the cervix, including carcinoma in situ. At present there is no evidence of this in humans despite 15 years' use. An estimated 10 million women have used Depo-provera.

In countries where maternal mortality and death from illegal abortions are high , several million women will die from unwanted and unplanned pregnancies in the final two decades of this century unless family planning and health services improve a great deal more rapidly than in the past. That information is contained in documents from the International Planned Parenthood Federation which discussed this matter. It is a matter of enormous concern to us here in Australia that every person who needs family planning advice and contraceptive advice receives the best advice possible. It is also a matter of considerable concern that the individual who is requesting that advice is given the full range of information, including indications for use and contra-indications. We want to be absolutely assured that, if the drug is to be used in Australia, the people who are using the drug-the practitioners-and those on whom it is being used are aware of what the consequences may be.

In some places there is no doubt that the Social Security staff are so appalled by the severity of the instructions that, rather than put people on special benefits which are difficult enough and which lose for beneficiaries a dollar for every additional dollar they earn above their benefit, they are suggesting to sick people that, if they can, they should stagger across to the Commonwealth Employment Office to register for work so that they can then claim the unemployment benefit. At least that will allow beneficiaries to earn $10 above their benefit without penalty. As a result, they receive less penalty than they would if they received the special benefit.

I hope that Senator Chaney will not immediately instruct his officers to try to prevent this. I am sure that not more than a handful of sick people who are entitled to the sickness benefit are now drawing the unemployment benefit rather than the special benefit. He and his colleagues need not worry; these people are still below the poverty line. They are still unable to claim the supplementary allowance or fringe benefits, so I am sure the Minister and his colleagues, who seem to be determined to cut down in this area, can rest easy.

Given that according to the answer of the Minister the cost of repealing this anomalous provision, which has arisen out of a decision by the policy section of the Department, is estimated to be about $10m in a full year-only 3.6 per cent of the estimated total cost of the sickness benefit this year-is the Minister trying to expedite the decision by the Government to rectify the injustice, an injustice that I think he recognises?

Finally, I can assure the Minister, certainly on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, that if he is considering the amendments to the Act which he alluded to in previous answers and if he is considering in the amending provisions of the Act an eligibility for full time housewives and full time students who are not normally members of the work force, he will get no argument at least from the Labor Party. I note that while I was absent the Minister took my name in vain and claimed that this advertising campaign was partly the result of my urgings that in fact the Government use radio and television to provide information to social security beneficiaries and potential beneficiaries in the community because in fact this is the most effective form of advertising.

I point out, as the Minister obviously knows, that my concern was that this advertising be continuous, be concerned with ensuring that people know just what benefits, pensions and other payments they are eligible for and under what circumstances, and be able to do this more effectively than the present method, largely that of handing out pamphlets through post offices or offices of the Department of Social Security. The smiling faces and references to family budgets in the present advertising is no more or less than political propaganda and is of very little assistance to those people in the community who need more information on the sorts of benefits, allowances and pensions which are available.

Finally, I raise a matter concerning another group of people in the community who are in a difficult situation. I refer to unemployed school leavers and their families. It decided not to pay that benefit until six weeks after the final examinations had been held or when they left school, whichever was the later. At the time, in spite of promises made by the then Minister for Social Security, now the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle), who is sitting with the present Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), family allowances and student allowances were also stopped over this period. In a time when unemployment is increasing-in some States the unemployment rate for young people in this age group is at a level of 33 1/3 per cent-and when, in an increasing number of cases, parents are unemployed, I wonder whether the Government has given any consideration to looking at this decision. Parents at this time have to feed growing young people with no less than average, or even more than average appetites, as Senator Chaney will learn as his children grow up. The Department of Social Security which has paid an allowance for those children since birth, cancels all of these payments at the very time when they need money for new clothes and transport, telephone money to hunt for work and food to sustain them . Government members, senior public servants and others have no problems with this policy. They manage to provide for family holidays and for this sort of expenditure. My concern is that it is the very poor families and, in particular, the unemployed parents-the parents who have been recently laid off in the considerable labour shedding that has occurred in all States in recent times-who not only have to explain to their children the difficulties of their present situation but also must do so when their family allowance and other allowances have been stopped and they are ineligible for the unemployment benefit. PROCTEXT.PARA: Mrs K. Beattie: Compensation Claim-Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills: Proposed Standing Order

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:
