SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the Senate but I wish to raise a matter which I first brought to its attention almost two years ago. It is a case which Senator Chaney, as the new Minister for Social Security at the time, took in hand. He undertook to give a firm and final response. We certainly then got a prompt response from the Minister for Social Security. The history of this case concerns Mrs Kathleen Beattie, who is a Canberra resident. Every time there appears to have been a decision in Mrs Beattie's favour the Crown, specifically the Department of Social Security, has refused to accept it. Nothing has been achieved for Mrs Beattie since Senator Chaney offered to take over the tangled bureaucratic mess and she is back in the same position she was in two years ago, facing large legal bills because the bureaucracy regards her case as a test case which she must not win. That is my reason for bringing up the matter again before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The background of Mrs Beattie's case is as follows: In 1978 she suffered an injury while on leave and later that injury was aggravated by her work in the Department of Housing and Construction. On 28 June 1979 a delegate of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation ruled against her claim for compensation, but on 10 January 1980 the Commissioner reversed this decision and Mrs Beattie was declared eligible for compensation. The Department of Social Security appealed against Mrs Beattie's successful decision to the Commonwealth Employees' Compensation Tribunal. The Tribunal ruled in Mrs Beattie's favour, so she had had her claim confirmed twice. The Department of Social Security again appealed against Mrs Beattie, lodging an appeal with the Federal Court of Australia on 1 May 1980. I repeat that the reason the Commonwealth has persisted in appealing again and again to frustrate Mrs Beattie's favourable decision being put into effect is that it regards her case as a test case. I certainly do not argue with that.

Mrs Beattie initially brought the matter to my attention not only because of the Commonwealth's determination to prevent payment of compensation to which the Tribunal said she was entitled but also because the Department of Social Security, in taking her to court endlessly, was landing her in extensive legal costs. At that stage her requests for legal assistance had been passed from one government department to another. It seemed to me at the time totally unfair that Mrs Beattie should have to bear costs in a High Court of Australia appeal when she had already won her case three times, and only because she was the innocent ex-public servant in a case which certainly had ramifications for the definition and application of what was called 'aggravation of injury'. For that reason I brought the case directly to Senator Chaney's notice in the Senate. He offered to pull the threads together to clear up the question of whether the Government would pay Mrs Beattie's legal expenses, as it was the Government that was keeping the case in court. In a phone call from Perth to Canberra on Christmas Eve in 1980 he assured her that she would not be up for those legal expenses. I certainly welcomed this clear and quick treatment of this difficult case but it was not, as everyone but the Department of Social Security hoped, the end of the matter.

The case went to the Federal Court and Mrs Beattie won again. The Department of Social Security gave instructions that Mrs Beattie was to be paid to 18 September 1980, but not after that. This further rejection of what Mrs Beattie claimed was her entitlement to compensation was then taken to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal which listed it for hearing. After further points of order from the Compensation Tribunal which was now within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as to whether the previous Tribunal's decision could be varied, the matter was relisted on 1 March 1982. On 5 March the Commissioner's office advised the Department of Social Security that the evidence supported the submission by Mrs Beattie's solicitors that she had been and still was totally incapacitated for work on and from 19 September, the Department previously deciding not to pay her from 18 September 1980. In fact, the evidence suggested that the incapacity was continuing. Because this was unacceptable to the Department of Social Security it decided to call the Deputy Crown Solicitor in to lodge an application for review within the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. That is where the matter rests at present, some four years after she first claimed compensation and some three years after she first successfully won her case.

In the past three years, as I have recounted, the Government particularly the Department of Social Security, has in fact fought her every inch of the way. I believe this is an extraordinary treatment of a former public servant and may be indicative of how little regard the Government has for its public servants. Mrs Beattie is wise and generous enough to acknowledge and accept that the Government has a problem with the concept of 'aggravation of injury' and it is entitled to seek a ruling which it believes is efficient and workable. I believe the bureaucracy has gone well beyond the bounds of what is reasonable in this case. For three years, as soon as the decision began going Mrs Beattie's way, the Government has put every obstacle in the way of allowing her to be paid compensation, compensation to which every tribunal in fact has agreed she is entitled.

This has been a time of anxiety for Mrs Beattie and her family. Not only has each victory been a hollow one because the Department has come back to attempt to reverse every favourable decision, but also the Department of Social Security has carried on not an equal fight but in fact what to many would seem a war of attrition against Mrs Beattie in the way in which it has used the endless resources of public servants, lawyers and finance. Mrs Beattie, on the other hand, has had only the resources of her husband's income and the family home apart from her own obvious spirit and perseverence. It is not, I suggest, a wilful perseverence but an honest struggle to obtain the right to compensation which the tribunals and the courts have consistently awarded her.

I am aware that the matter is before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Nowhere in this speech have I canvassed the particulars on which a determination will be made. I am bringing the matter up tonight essentially for the same reason that I raised it two years ago; that is, the inequity of resources in a legal battle which is being fought by the Department against Mrs Beattie. There are cases in which it may be reasonable to expect costs to be borne by a person taking on government departments, but I suggest this is not such a case. I repeat that it is a test case which the Government has brought again and again against a former public servant who has received four favourable verdicts from the appropriate tribunals and courts.

The principle the Government wishes to establish may well be legitimate but it is not legitimate, I suggest, to put someone like this through three years of anxiety and litigation in what could well be construed as an attempt to wear her down. In particular, she should not be put in a position of being potentially bankrupted by legal costs in an adversary situation in which the Government has unlimited funds against an individual of modest means. I ask the Minister for Social Security to reconsider the situation in which his Department has placed Mrs Beattie. I ask him whether there is any justice in the refusal of the Government to give Mrs Beattie legal aid so that she can be properly represented before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and have some kind of an equal chance . I know that I raised this question some months ago, but I have not received a reply as yet. I think this is an important matter as I thought it was two years ago. We have a situation in which someone has taken on the Department legally, through the tribunals and the courts, and has persistently won. I admit that she has won decisions which have raised difficulties for the Department. I think at this stage, as I believed two years ago, that she or her family should not be faced with potential bankruptcy or put into any sort of financial difficulty in pursuing what she and others have seen in the past as the justice of her case. I ask the Minister to take up this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to express my shock and indignation at the treatment which the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has received this week at the hands of the Standing Orders Committee which has failed so far to approve the new Standing Order which would enable that Committee to be put now on a permanent basis. I received your letter only today, Mr President, which indicated that this matter apparently has been deferred and has not been approved. I am amazed as to what has happened regarding this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The position is that the Senate approved the setting up of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in permanent form some few weeks ago. The Senate had debated that matter and it had a Government response. The Committee's ninth report set out in detail the Standing Order which we proposed. The report set out the various arguments why we felt that the Committee should operate in certain ways. Nobody in this chamber criticised any aspect of the Standing Order or the proposals of the Committee, which were adopted unanimously by the Senate and which so far have been frustrated by the Standing Orders Committee of this chamber.

Last week, I learnt that the matter was to come up before the Standing Orders Committee on Tuesday of this week. One of the Clerks expressed a view that there might be some criticism of the terms of the Standing Order. I pointed out that the terms had already been approved by the Senate and it was a matter surely of technical detail only. I said to the Clerk that, if any problem arose, I would be in the chamber or in Parliament House last night and would be ready to go into the meeting at any time to explain anything that was required. It is important to remember so far as this Committee is concerned that it has now been hanging on for some months without being put on its final and permanent basis. It is important that a new chairman should be appointed to the Committee and that its new membership be appointed before the Senate rises for the Christmas recess so that the Committee can start off the next year in its permanent form.
In your letter to me of today's date, Mr President, you said:

At its meeting last night the Standing Orders Committee considered the question of the adoption of a standing order to establish the Scrutiny of Bills Committee on a permanent basis, referred to it by the Senate on 28 October 1982.

There is something which is a little incorrect about that. The Committee has always been on a permanent basis. There has never been anything tentative about this Committee. What has been tentative has been the separate membership of it. The Committee has the same membership as the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in this trial period. That is unsatisfactory. Some members on that Committee are not able to devote their time to the business and want to get off the Committee. It is altogether very unsatisfactory to wreck a committee such as the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee because of the week by week requirements which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee imposes.
Mr President, in your letter you go on to say:

During discussion on the matter members of the Committee drew attention to a number of provisions contained in the proposed new standing order, as recommended by the Ninth Report of your Committee, which were not contained in the original resolution of appointment on 19 November 1981 and appear to be taken from standing order 36AA relating to the legislative and General Purpose Standing Committees. Members referred to what they believed had been the original expectation, as implied in the 1981 resolution, that the Committee would operate in a manner similar to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, rather than those Standing Committees, and queried the necessity for the expanded provisions.

I do not know where the members of the Committee got that interpretation from. In my opinion the Standing Orders in regard to the Regulations and Ordinances Committee are fairly outdated and are unsatisfactory. The Committee has been operating for over 50 years. That matter needs some review. What the committee for the Scrutiny of Bills is doing is very much in accord with the types of inquiries the standing committees now undertake. We thought that the powers we recommended which were adopted by the Senate, were appropriate to this new Committee. I have no idea why it was thought that the Committee would operate just like the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. Mr President, you finished your letter by stating:
The Committee has asked me to ascertain whether the Scrutiny of Bills Committee , in recommending the proposed standing order, had any particular reasons for adopting those particular provisions.

I think we had good reason for that. But at all stages we were adequately ready to explain those matters to the Committee. It was absolutely vital that the standing Orders be set up this week so that the Committee could, thereby, have the opportunity of getting a new membership, so that the various parties could nominate their members and so that the Committee could operate from next week.

I must say that I am absolutely fed up with this treatment from the Standing Orders Committee. I insist that the Committee should meet again before this week is out and that it should hear from members of the Security of Bills Committee. If the members of the Standing Orders Committee wish to revoke the decision of the Senate-the Senate has approved of the ninth report and the recommendation we made-we will face them on the floor of the Senate. I think we should know the reasons for their actions. I do not know why the members of the Committee did not raise these objections when the matter was being debated in the Senate. They choose to do it now at the end of the session when it is impossible to make other arrangements. It is clear that unless my plea gets somewhere in this chamber the matter will be left over to the new year. Frankly, as a matter of protest, I will probably resign from the chairmanship of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee if I do not get some satisfaction in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Grimes has raised in the adjournment debate tonight the case of Mrs Beattie and, in particular, her request for further legal aid. Like Senator Grimes, I would wish to avoid canvassing the facts of the case because, as he indicated, the matter is before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I think it would trespass against the rules of this place to go into the facts of the matter and, in any event, I think it would be generally undesirable to do so. The grant of legal aid is generally a matter for the Attorney-General's Department rather than the Department of Social Security. The provision of legal aid is usually a matter which is determined according to the means of the person who is seeking the aid, although there are exceptions to that. There are circumstances in which, irrespective of means, aid will be granted.

SPEECH.PARA: When Senator Grimes intervened some time ago and when I also, as a result, was involved in the matter the aid granted at that time was granted on the basis of an exception which was defined in, I think, the early 1970s or probably the late 1960s in relation to taxation cases but which has been applied more broadly- namely, that if a case is being fought, in part, because of its test case nature legal aid should be extended. Although I have not refreshed my memory on the statement on which that was based-I think it was a statement of then Treasurer McMahon-Mrs Beattie's case was considered and thought at that time to be a test case. I should make it clear that in the very lengthy series of proceedings in which Mrs Beattie has been engaged there have in fact been different periods under consideration.

I do not think it would trespass against my opening remarks to say that Mrs Beattie, having fought and won a series of legal engagements in the course of which she received legal aid assistance, as I have just indicated, was paid what she was entitled to and her costs. There were then subsequent proceedings which relate to a later period. It is with respect to those subsequent proceedings-the current proceedings-that legal aid is now sought. I understand that it has been refused because the applicant does not come within the means tests which are applied. In addition, it is not considered that the current action, relating to a later time, is in the nature of a test case.

In response to Senator Grimes, and in response to the direct representations I have had from Mrs Beattie, I propose to seek some guidance from the Attorney- General's Department on the issue of whether Mrs Beattie is still engaged in a test case or is simply engaged in a dispute over a set of facts. In other words, I will seek further advice and will further examine her present entitlement to legal aid.

I am aware that, for most Australians, involvement in litigation is not without difficulty. I am aware that the provision of legal aid generally means that people of only very modest means receive assistance. So, on the one hand I can understand that Mrs Beattie has some difficulty. On the other, I believe that difficulty is not unique to Mrs Beattie and her case should be judged according to the same sort of criteria as would be applied in any other case. However, I will seek further advice and in the light thereof further examine the matter to ensure that she is, within the currently applicable rules relating to the availability of aid, given fair treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) No. Until 1980 the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs made available separate leaflets in a number of languages to help travellers complete the cards. Printing of these leaflets was discontinued because the Department found there was little demand for them.

(3) No. Details must be entered in the manual and computerised records in English must be examined by officers involved in clearing passengers. With nearly 5 million passenger movements per annum at seaports and airports throughout Australia, it is not feasible to provide immediate translation facilities at every point of entry in every language that could be encountered.

It might be useful to point out that the number of words required to answer questions on the card is kept to a minimum. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 14 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Government aware that employees of the Australian Shipping Commission (trading as the Australian National Line-ANL) must make a choice, by 1 December 1982, between remaining in the general Commonwealth Public Service superannuation scheme or moving to the scheme operated by the ANL.
(2) Why has the Government failed to inform ANL employees of its long-term intentions regarding the Commonwealth Public Service scheme.

(3) Can the Government give an undertaking to ANL employees that, even though employee/government contributions may not cover projected benefits, those benefits under the Commonwealth Public Service superannuation scheme will not be trimmed back in future.
(4) Will the Government, in order to be fair, clarify by the 1 December 1982 the long-term implications contained in the superannuation options currently being offered to ANL employees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Employees of the Australian Shipping Commission have been given a choice either to remain in the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme or to transfer to the proposed new ANL Staff Superannuation Scheme. The details of the ANL scheme are still being developed. Any deadline by which ANL staff must make the election is a matter for the Commission.

(2) to (4) ANL has provided its employees who are contributors to the Commonwealth scheme with comparative information on the two schemes so that those employees may make an informed choice. ANL staff who decide to remain in the Commonwealth scheme will be treated no differently from other members of that scheme. The questions appear to imply that the level of benefits payable under the Commonwealth scheme to employees of particular authorities is dependent upon the adequacy or otherwise of the contributions paid by that authority. This is not the case. The level of benefits under the scheme, and the circumstances in which they become payable, are defined in the Superannuation Act 1976. They do not depend upon the rate of contribution (if any) paid by particular employing authorities. The Superannuation Act provides that the Government-financed element of all benefits shall be met from the Consolodated Revenue Fund at the time the benefits become payable, and that employee-financed benefits payable at that time are confined to the amount of each member's contributions accumulated with interest earned, or the equivalent unindexed pension. There is no guarantee that employee-financed benefits will be of any particular amount, or will bear any particular relationship to the employee's pre-retirement salary.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1982 (Hansard, page 283) Senator Martin asked Senator Durack, as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, without notice, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister seen an article in the 16 August 1982 issue of the Newsweek magazine headed 'The Mail Order Brides' which refers to the growing number-1, 500 in 1981-of marriages between Philippine women and Australian men arranged through marriage agencies? I am sure all honourable senators have seen these agencies' advertisements in major Australian newspapers. Does the Minister share my concern at the allegations in the article that Philippine women reportedly have been beaten, have been given little or no money, and have kept virtual prisoners in their husbands' houses? In view of the particular nature of this section of the marriage industry that is specific to the Philippine women, will the Government consider legislating to require that these women be given, in advance of migrating to Australia, a full description of their legal rights in Australia after marriage?
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have seen the Newsweek article headed 'The Mail Order Brides'. There is, however, little reliable data on the extent of social problems being experienced and it appears that many marriages in fact work out quite well. Nevertheless, I share your concern about possible social problems arising from these marriages.

The situation has been the subject of discussions between officials of the Philippines Government, senior Departmental officers, members of the Filipino community in Australia and social workers. A study of the experiences and problems associated with these marriages is being undertaken by my Department in Melbourne in consultation with the Filipino community there. The results of the study should identify particular problems and allow them to be specifically addressed.

Difficulties can arise in marriages where both partners come from different cultural backgrounds. To help overcome such difficulties, officers of my Department seek to provide counselling including some advice on legal rights to Filipinos and their Australian husbands prior to the issue of migrant entry visas.

The answer to many of the problems which can be associated with these marriages lies in both partners understanding their position and each other's position more thoroughly. I believe that counselling is much more effective at achieving this than legislation.

For this reason, the Government is not considering legislation to require that these women be given, in advance of migrating to Australia, a full description of their legal rights in Australia after marriage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 September 1982 (Hansard, page 1036) Senator Reid asked a question without notice of me, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate, in the absence of Senator Durack. The question concerned an item on the 60 Minutes television program which referred to the 'whingeing Pom' syndrome.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Officers of my Department take care to ensure that people interviewed overseas with a view to settling in Australia are fully informed about current conditions here to ensure that as far as possible they have realistic expectations of life in Australia. For those who undertake the on-arrival information program, this information is supplemented by further counselling after arrival.

Migration officers interviewing people overseas who will require employment on arrival advise them of their prospects in accordance with the Occupation Demand Schedule produced by the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. However, people do not always leave for Australia immediately after approval and successful applicants are counselled to up-date their information about employment prospects immediately before departure.

Whatever the quality and thoroughness of pre-embarkation briefing, a small proportion of migrants meet settlement difficulties caused by their own personal circumstances including homesickness and emotional and domestic upsets . Mostly these are resolved.

In the first six months of 1981/82, a total of 2,355 former settlers departed Australia permanently within two years of arrival. This is a very small number compared with the size of the immigration intake. Of this number, some 850 would have been people returning to the United Kingdom.
Not all people who depart Australia are necessarily dissatisfied with Australia.
